Misconception 0/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "\[
8 + 5 \times 3 - 2
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 19 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (8+5) \times 3 - 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 + (5 \times 3) - 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 + 5 \times (3 - 2) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not need brackets",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before multiplication "
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator",
            "Subject": "Simplifying Algebraic Fractions",
            "Question": "Simplify the following, if possible: \( \frac{x^{2}+5 x+6}{x+3} \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x+2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x+1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks that when you cancel identical terms from the numerator and denominator, they just disappear"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not simplify",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 2/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the range from a list of data",
            "Subject": "Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data",
            "Question": "Lucy and David are discussing the \( 5 \) students with these quiz scores:
\( 82, 70, 95, 78, 65 \)
Lucy says if all the students lost \( 5 \) points on the quiz, the range wouldn't change.
David says if all the students scored \( 2 \) times their current score, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Lucy",
                "Misconception": "Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only David",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Lucy and David",
                "Misconception": "Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Believes if you add the same value to all numbers in the dataset the range will change"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 4/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Substitute positive integer values into formulae involving powers or roots",
            "Subject": "Substitution into Formula",
            "Question": "The equation \( f=2r^{2} - 4 \) is used to find values in the table below. What is the value covered by the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( r \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( f \) & \( -2 \) & \( 4 \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) & \( 26 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}"

        "answers": {

            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks you can find missing values in a given table by treating the row as linear and adding on the difference between the first two values given."

        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify a unit of area",

\(

\)

Misconception 8/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Fractions",
            "Question": "\(
\frac{3}{8}-\frac{2}{5}=\frac{\bigstar}{40}
\)
What should replace the star?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 47 \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of subtracts"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 12 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D" is incorrect in the original response. In the corrected response the answer that is actually  "1" is  answer D: (6 - 4) and 40 (the denominator) would make 16 (in a common denominator) result in the correct D value which would be 1 making another correct response "A" )

Misconception 9/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify horizontal translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions",
            "Subject": "Transformations of functions in the form f(x)",
            "Question": "What transformation maps the graph of 
\(y=f(x)\) 
to the graph of 
\(
y=f(x+2)
\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Translation by vector 
\(
\left[\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
2
\end{array}\right]
\)",
                "Misconception": "Believes f(x - a) translates the function up a units"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Translation by vector 
\(
\left[\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
-2
\end{array}\right]
\)",
                "Misconception": "Believes f(x + a) translates the function up a units"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Translation by vector 
\(
\left[\begin{array}{l}
-2 \\
0
\end{array}\right]
\)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Translation by vector 
\(
\left[\begin{array}{r}
2 \\
0
\end{array}\right]
\)",
                "Misconception": "Believes f(x) + a translates the function right a units"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 10/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Expand products of three binomials in the form (x + a)(x + b)(x + c)",
            "Subject": "Expanding Triple Brackets and more",
            "Question": "Emily is expanding these three brackets:
\(
(x+4)(x-2)(x+3)
\)

She finds it helpful to split the first bracket and view the problem as follows:
\(
x(x-2)(x+3)+4(x-2)(x+3)
\)

She expands the brackets further. Before she simplifies, what are the terms that contain an \( \boldsymbol{x}^{2} \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( +3 x^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}+3 x^{2} \\ -2 x^{2} \\ +4 x^{2}\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}+3 x^{2} \\ +2 x^{2} \\ +4 x^{2}\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}+3 x^{2} \\ -2 x^{2} \\ -4 x^{2}\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"

Misconception 12/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify alternate angles",
            "Subject": "Angle Facts with Parallel Lines",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are arguing about alternate angles.
Alex says angles \( a \) and \( b \) are alternate.

Ben says angles \( a \) and \( b \) are equal.
Who is correct? ![Shows two non-parallel lines that are intersected by another line. Angles A and B are both on the outside of the lines and on opposite sides of the transversal.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Thinks alternate angles are always equal"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "Thinks alternate angles are always equal"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Thinks only angles on parallel lines can be alternate"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }

Misconception 14/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy",
            "Subject": "Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods",
            "Question": "\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{3}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=2 \), what is the solution to \( x=10-\frac{3}{x} \) to \( 3 \) decimal places?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.14 \)",
                "Misconception": "Stops iteration too early when solving equations"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.14473\ldots \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (significant figures rather than decimal places)"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.145 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 15/1869:
Here is another question based on the same format and misconceptions:

[{
    "question": {
        "ConstructName": "Calculate the area of an equilateral triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units",
        "Subject": "Area of Simple Shapes",
        "Question": "How would you calculate the area of this equilateral triangle? ![A triangle, base 15cm. All three sides are equal.]()"
    },
    "answers": {
        "Answer_A": {
            "Answer_text": "\( \frac{7.5 \times 15}{2} \)",
            "Misconception": "nan"
        },
        "Answer_B": {
            "Answer_text": "\( \frac{15 \times 15}{2} \)",
            "Misconception": "Has used slant height and base to find area of a triangle rather than perpendicular height and base"
        },
        "Answer_C": {
            "Answer_text": "\( \frac{15 \times 15 \times 15}{2} \)",
            "Misconception": "Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area"
        },
        "Answer_D": {
            "Answer_text": "None of these",
            "Misconception": "nan"
        }
    },
    "Correct_Answer": "D"
}]

Misconception 16/1869:
```json
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Divide a quantity into two parts for a given a ratio, where each part is an integer",
            "Subject": "Sharing in a Ratio",
            "Question": "The length of a rectangular garden is divided into two parts. If the ratio of the garden's patio area to the rest of the garden \( =2: 3 \) and the total length of the garden is 50 m, what is the length of the patio area? ![A rectangular garden divided into two parts by a line.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 25 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "Divides total amount by each side of the ratio instead of dividing by the sum of the parts"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up sides of a ratio"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "Finds one part of a ratio but doesn't multiply that by the number of parts needed"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Misconception 17/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Prove statements involving odd and even numbers",
            "Subject": "Ordering Negative Numbers",
            "Question": "Which of these shows part of the proof that the product of an even number and an odd number is even?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}(2 n-1)(2 m+1) \\ =2(m n+n-m)+1\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that 2n represents an even number"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}(2 n+1)(2 m-1) \\ =4 m n-2 n-2 m-1 \\ =2(2 m n-m-n)-1\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the meaning of the word "product""
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Odd } \times\text { even } \\ =\text { odd }\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that 2n represents an even number"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}(2 n)(2 m+1) \\ =4 m n+2 n \\ =2(2 m n+n)\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 19/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions",
            "Question": "Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{2}{x} - \frac{y}{5} \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{2-y}{5x} \)",
                "Misconception": "When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and multiplies the denominators"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{5-2y}{5x} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes they should multiply each numerator by its original denominator when adding/subtracting fractions"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{10-xy}{5x} \)",
                "Misconception": ""
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{2-y}{x-5} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not find a common denominator when adding/subtracting fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 21/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² + bx + c where a is prime",
            "Subject": "Factorising into a Double Bracket",
            "Question": "Step 1: Factorise the following expression

\(
5 x^{2}+7 x+2
\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (5 x+2)(5 x+1) \)",
                "Misconception": "When factorising a quadratic with a non-unit coefficient of x squared, believes that coefficient will be in front of both x terms in the factorised form"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (5 x+2)(x+1) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Cannot be factorised",
                "Misconception": "Fails to understand that all quadratic expressions can be factored into the product of two binomials provided the coefficient of the squared term is prime"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (5 x+1)(x+2) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that if the quadratic cannot be factored, the answer is to stick to the two number coefficients of x from the original equation in the brackets but use their addition in reverse within the two factors"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 22/1869:
[
  {
    "question": {
      "ConstructName": "Given the solution to one problem, deduce the answer to a related problem using the same operation",
      "Subject": "Mental Addition and Subtraction",
      "Question": "Ben and Alex are discussing related calculations
Ben says if you know that \( 9632+189=9821 \), then \( 9632+190 \) must equal \( \mathbf{9 8 2 2} \)

Alex says if you know that \( 9632-189=9443 \), then \( 9632 \) - \( 190 \) must equal \( \mathbf{9 4 4 3} \)
Who is correct?"
    },
    "answers": {
      "Answer_A": {
        "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
        "Misconception": "nan"
      },
      "Answer_B": {
        "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
        "Misconception": "Does not realise that adding a larger number gives a larger answer"
      },
      "Answer_C": {
        "Answer_text": "Both Ben and Alex",
        "Misconception": "Does not realise that subtracting a larger number will give a smaller answer"
      },
      "Answer_D": {
        "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
        "Misconception": "nan"
      }
    },
    "Correct_Answer": "A"
  }
]

        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "The hiker is descending",
                "Misconception": "nan"

                "Misconception": "Confuses rest and movement on a distance time graph"
            },

                "Answer_text": "The hiker is gaining speed",
                "Misconception": "Believes the gradient of a distance-time graph is the acceleration"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "The hiker is moving further from the starting point",
                "Misconception": "Believes a downward slope on a distance-time graph means travelling away"

Misconception 29/1869:
Here's another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve linear inequalities in one variable where the unknown appears on boths sides of the equation",
            "Subject": "Solving Linear Inequalities",
            "Question": "Solve
\[
4 x - 2 \leq 2 x + 8
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x \leq 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \leq x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x \geq 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes they can multiply/divide through by a negative number without changing the direction of the inequality"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -5 \leq x \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

To solve it correctly: 
\( 4x - 2 \leq 2x + 8 \) 
\( 4x - 2x \leq 8 + 2 \) 
\( 2x \leq 10 \) 
\( x \leq 5 \)

Misconception 33/1869:
Here's another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "A bucket is being filled with sand at a constant rate.

This graph shows how the volume \( (V) \) of sand in the bucket changes over time \( (t) \).

Which of the following buckets is this most likely to be the graph of? ![A volume-time graph which is a curve starting at (0, 0), with a steep gradient to begin with but then the gradient decreases and the graph levels off to almost horizontal.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A conical bucket sitting on its circular base.]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not interpret a sloping gradient as a change in rate"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A wide cylindrical bucket with a narrow cylindrical container at its side.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A rectangular prism bucket with a smaller rectangular prism on top.]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not spot the difference between a gradual change of gradient and 2 distinct line segments with different constant gradients"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A bucket with an uneven cross-sectional area, with a narrow bottom and flared sides.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Convert decimals less than 1 with 1 decimal place to percentages",

            "Question": "Convert this decimal to a percentage
\[
0.8
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 80 \% \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \% \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.8 \% \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks you need to just add a % sign to a decimal to convert to a percentage"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.008 \% \)",
                "Misconception": "Divides instead of multiplies when converting a decimal to a percentage"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 36/1869:

        {
            "question": {

                "Question": "Simplify the following by collecting like terms. \[

\]"
            },
            "answers": {
                "Answer_A": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( 3 \times b \)",
                    "Misconception": "Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions"
                },
                "Answer_B": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( b 3 \)",
                    "Misconception": "Writes the variable before the coefficient in an algebraic term"
                },
                "Answer_C": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( 3 b \)",
                    "Misconception": "nan"
                },
                "Answer_D": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( b^{3} \)",
                    "Misconception": "Confuses collecting like terms with multiplication"
                }
            },
            "Correct_Answer": "C"
        }
    ]

Misconception 40/1869:
Here's another example based on the same misconception for each answer provided:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Read values off a real life graph",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "A water tank can hold a total of 500 liters of water. The water tank is filled at a rate of 2 liters per minute for the first 200 liters. After that, it is filled at a rate of 1 liter per minute. How long will it take to fill the water tank? ![A graph showing how the amount of water changes for different number of minutes. The first 200 liters are filled at 2 liters/minute. Then the rate changes to 1 liter/minute.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "600 minutes",
                "Misconception": "Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "250 minutes",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "300 minutes",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "450 minutes",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 41/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {

            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 170 \)",
                "Misconception": "Added the values together instead of finding the percentage"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Impossible as you cannot have a percentage greater than \( 100 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that you can have percentages greater than 100%"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Explanation for the correct answer (Answer B): 
To calculate 120% of 50, you need to find 20% of 50 and add it to 100% of 50. 
20% of 50 = 0.2 * 50 = 10 
100% of 50 = 50 
120% of 50 = 100% + 20% = 50 + 10 = 60 
So, 120% of 50 is 60.

    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the mean from a frequency table",
            "Subject": "Averages and Range from Frequency Table",
            "Question": "This table shows the number of books a group of students reads in a month.
If calculating the mean number of books read, what would replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of books & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 8 \) & \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 10 \) & \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 6 \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \)
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 4 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3+6=9 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the fx column for calculating mean is value + frequency"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3-6=(-3) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the fx column for calculating mean is value - frequency"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \times 6=18 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \div 6=0.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the fx column for calculating mean is value/frequency"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 64/1869:
Here's another example based on the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, involving positive decimals",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Solve the equation:
\[
0.24=0.08 x
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=\frac{1}{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes division is commutative "
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=0.192 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, multiplies instead of dividing "
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=0.32 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```

In this example, the correct solution would be to divide 0.24 by 0.08, resulting in x = 3.

Misconception 76/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recall and use the intersecting diagonals properties of a rhombus",
            "Subject": "Properties of Quadrilaterals",
            "Question": "The diagonals of a rhombus \(_____________\) bisect each other at right-angles ![A rhombus]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "never",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the properties of a rectangle"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "sometimes",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the properties of a rectangle"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "always",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "I don't know",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the properties of a rectangle"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Note: Although a rhombus is a type of quadrilateral, it is different from a rectangle. However, I am generating another example based on the misconception that is given. In a rhombus, the diagonals always bisect each other at right angles.

                "Answer_text": "\( 130^{\circ} \)",

            },

                "Misconception": "nan"
            }

        "Correct_Answer": "E"
    }

Misconception 107/1869:
Here's another example for each answer choice maintaining the same format and misconceptions:

```json
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Divide proper fractions in the form: Integer ÷ Fraction",
            "Subject": "Dividing Fractions",
            "Question": "How many times does \( \frac{2}{3} \) go into \( 12 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{24}{36} \)",
                "Misconception": "When dividing an integer by a fraction, thinks they multiply numerator and denominator by the integer"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 36 \)",
                "Misconception": "When dividing by a non unit fraction, thinks you multiply by the reciprocal of the corresponding unit fraction rather than the fraction given."
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "when dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies the numerator by the integer"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 18 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

The key calculation for this problem is \( 12 \div \frac{2}{3} = 12 \times \frac{3}{2} = 18 \).

Misconception 108/1869:
Here's another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Carry out multiplication problems involving one negative integer",
            "Subject": "Expanding Double Brackets",
            "Question": "Sarah is expanding these two brackets.

What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The two brackets are (x+2)(x-9). The arrows are pointing at the +2 in the first bracket and the -9 in the second bracket.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -7 \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -18 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( +11 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( +18 \)",
                "Misconception": "Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

```
                "Answer_text": "\( x=\frac{-51}{16} \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, multiplies instead of adding"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Misconception 154/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate time where speed and distance are in the appropriate units",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "Astrid is cycling to her friend's house. This displacement-time graph shows the first part of her journey.

During that time she travelled at a speed of \( 2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).
What are the coordinates of the marked point? ![The vertical axis of the graph is labelled Distance (m) and has a scale marked from 0 to 80 in even steps. The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has no scale marked on it. The graph is a straight line that goes from point (0,80) and touches the Time axis four squares from the origin (0,0).
The marked point is two squares in on the Time axis and at 30 on the Distance axis.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {

            },

                "Misconception": "Makes an assumption about the squares on a scale representing either 1 or 10"

                "Misconception": "Believes scales on graphs must match on both axes"

                    "Answer_text": "\( 15 \)",
                    "Misconception": "Adds instead of multiples"
                },
                "Answer_C": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( 555 \)",
                    "Misconception": "When asked to triple, writes the digit out three times"
                },
                "Answer_D": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( 15 \)",
                    "Misconception": "nan"
                }
            },
            "Correct_Answer": "D"

                "Answer_text": "\( y=5 x-4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes lines are parallel if they have the same y intercept "
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=-4 - x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=5(0.2+x) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=8 \frac{1}{4} \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=7 \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding an integer to a fraction, thinks you add the integer to the numerator"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=-1 \frac{1}{4} \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=1 \frac{3}{4} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }

Misconception 212/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Represent a linear inequality in the form x ≤ a or x ≥ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline",
            "Subject": "Inequalities on Number Lines",
            "Question": "Which of the following diagrams represents \( x \geq -3 \) or \( x < 1 \) ?"
        },

  {

\(

\)
"
    },
    "answers": {
      "Answer_A": {
        "Answer_text": "\(\color{green}\bigcirc\) = +7",
        "Misconception": "nan"
      },
      "Answer_B": {
        "Answer_text": "\(\color{green}\bigcirc\) = +0 
(no number term)",
        "Misconception": "Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets"
      },
      "Answer_C": {
        "Answer_text": "\(\color{green}\bigcirc\) = +1",
        "Misconception": "Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer"
      },
      "Answer_D": {
        "Answer_text": "\(\color{green}\bigcirc\) = -3",
        "Misconception": "nan"
      }
    },
    "Correct_Answer": "D",
    "Explanation": "(a-2)(a+5) = a^2 +5a -2a -10, 
the correct answer comes from the part (-2a -10). No other answers' misconceptions match."
  }
]

Misconception 249/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable",
            "Subject": "Simultaneous Equations",
            "Question": "Sarah and Alex are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}2 x+5 y=3 \\ 2 x-5 y=9\end{array} \) Sarah says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Alex says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Sarah",
                "Misconception": "Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Sarah and Alex",
                "Misconception": "When solving simultaneous equations thinks that identical terms in given equations can be eliminated by either adding or subtracting."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

```
    {

                "Answer_text": "\( 0 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the first significant value is the first non-zero digit number"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0 \)",
```

\( 4x-5z=11 \) & \( 4x+5z=11 \)
\end{array}

    {
        "question": {

            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 73^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "Misinterprets the meaning of angles on a straight line angle fact"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 21^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Not enough information",
                "Misconception": "Does not know that angles on a straight line sum to 180 degrees"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

            },

                "Misconception": "Believes the whole and remainder are the other way when changing an improper fraction to a mixed number"

Misconception 256/1869:
Here's another example in the same format and with the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use area to write algebraic expressions",
            "Subject": "Expanding Single Brackets",
            "Question": "The area of these shapes are equal. Which of these is correct? ![An image of two rectangles. The top one is blue and has the dimensions - side length: 3 and base 2x + 3. The bottom one is yellow and has the dimensions - side length: 6 and base x - 1.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 x+9=6 x-6 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 x+3=2 x+6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9+8 x=12+2 x+6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Calculates perimeter when asked for area"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3+2 x+3=x+6-1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Substitute negative integer values into formulae involving powers or roots",
            "Subject": "Substitution into Formula",
            "Question": "\( G=2^{b} \)

What is the value of \( G \) when \( b=-3 \)?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -8 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a negative power results in a negative answer"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -\frac{1}{8} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a negative power results in a negative answer"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Has multiplied the base number and the power"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{1}{8} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

        "question": {

                "Misconception": "nan"

    }

            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "D",
                "Misconception": "Gives the vertex instead of the 3-letter angle notation"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]


However, another more similar example can come from altering parts of the square.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)",
            "Subject": "Types, Naming and Estimating",
            "Question": "Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square GJKL. M lies 1/3 from K on the line KL and is connected to G by a line. Attached to the square at line KL is a pentagon KLMPQ. P is connected to K and L by lines. The angle highlighted is the entire, interior angle at L.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "PLG",
                "Misconception": "Gives 3-letter angle notation in the wrong order"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "MGL",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "GLP",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "L",
                "Misconception": "Gives the vertex instead of the 3-letter angle notation"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 311/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one",
            "Subject": "Linear Sequences (nth term)",
            "Question": "Alex and Mia are arguing about the best way to count the number of cubes in Pattern \( 20 \). 
Alex does: \( 20 \times 2+1 \)
Mia does: \( (20-3) \times 2+7 \)
Who is correct? ![The 2nd and 3rd terms in a sequence of patterns. Each pattern is made from blue cubes. Pattern 2 is 7 cubes: they are arranged as a rectangle, 2 squares high and 2 squares wide and then 3 more cubes, 1 each side of the middle cubes (horizontally). Pattern 3 is 9 cubes arranged as a rectangle, 2 squares high and 3 squares wide and then 3 more cubes, 1 each side of the middle cubes.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Believes nth term rules for patterns must be given in standard an + b form"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Mia",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Mia",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Believes nth term rules for patterns must be given in standard an + b form"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 320/1869:
Here's another example in the same format, following the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units",
            "Subject": "Compound Area",
            "Question": "Calculate the total area of this compound shape composed of rectangles. ![Compound shape made of three rectangles with the sides labelled 8 cm, 5 cm, 2 cm and 6 cm. One side is unlabelled]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 480 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 48 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Makes an assumption about line segments being equal within a shape"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 88 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 90 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Uses an incorrect side length when splitting a composite shape into parts"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Corrected and re-Organized Output
 [
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Multiply a decimal by an integer",
            "Subject": "Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals",
            "Question": "Work out: \[
0.5 \times 8
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 40 \)",
                "Misconception": "When multiplying decimals, ignores place value and just multiplies the digits"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.4 \)",
                "Misconception": "When multiplying a decimal less than 1 by an integer, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.04 \)",
                "Misconception": "When multiplying a decimal less than 1 by an integer, gives an answer 100 times smaller than it should be"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 323/1869:
Here's another example based on the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c",
            "Subject": "Factorising into a Double Bracket",
            "Question": "Factorise \( x^{2}+14 x+48 \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+6)(x+8) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+3)(x+16) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+4)(x+48) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+7)(x+13) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Note: The correct answer is (x+3)(x+16) because the numbers 3 and 16 multiply to give 48 and add to give 19, which is not possible. However, among the answer choices provided 3 and 16 add to give 19 and 8 and 6 add to give 14 (the correct factor which was 16 and 3 had their values interchanged and used to create the Answer_A choice provided where values 6 and 8 effectively work to match the coefficient which has been set as 14 in x^2 + 14x + 48.)

The only two integers which multiply to 48 and add up to 14 are 6 and 8 which factorises into (x + 6)(x + 8).

Misconception 324/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify a kite from a description of the properties",
            "Subject": "Properties of Polygons",
            "Question": "Which of the following quadrilaterals could not be classified as a kite?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Rectangle",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise the properties of a kite"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Parallelogram",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise the properties of a kite"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Triangle",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "None of the above",
                "Misconception": "Does not believe a shape can have two correct names e.g. rectangle and parallelogram"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 328/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Fractions",
            "Question": "Calculate:
\(

\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{12} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{16} \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{12} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not consider the denominator when adding/ subtracting fractions. Adds/subtracts the numerator and makes the denominator the one with the highest value."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{1}{6} \)",
                "Misconception": "Subtracts instead of adds"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 180 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 177 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    },
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Round non-integers to the nearest 10",

```
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}A=\frac{1}{2}(3.8)+4.2 \\ A=6.8\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks two variables next to each other represent addition"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}A=\frac{1}{2}(3.8+4.2) \\ A=4\end{array} \)",

            },

                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}A=3.8+4.2+\left(\frac{1}{2} \times 1\right) \\ A=8.2\end{array} \)",
```

Misconception 350/1869:
Here's another example of the same question in JSON format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1",
            "Subject": "Probability of Single Events",
            "Question": "A coin is flipped and the probability of landing heads is \( \frac{3}{5} \). What is the probability of the coin landing tails?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks that probabilities of an event occurring or not occurring must be equal"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{2}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Gives probability as an integer instead of a fraction"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3}{10} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 351/1869:
Here's a new example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the square of a number",
            "Subject": "Squares, Cubes, etc",
            "Question": "\( (25)^{2}=? \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 12.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up squaring with dividing by 2"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 50 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 625 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 15625 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

However, as 625 is the correct answer not D for the \( (25)^{2} \). 

Let me give you the correct alternative:

 [
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the square of a number",
            "Subject": "Squares, Cubes, etc",
            "Question": "\( (8)^{2}=? \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up squaring with dividing by 2"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 64 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 512 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 352/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c",
            "Subject": "Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values",
            "Question": "This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\( y = x^2 - 3 \)  \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 22 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes addition comes before indices, in orders of operation"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 13 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -28 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the square of a negative will also be negative"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 357/1869:
Here's the new example:

[
 {
  "question": {
   "ConstructName": "Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention",
   "Subject": "Writing Expressions",
   "Question": "Which of the following is the correct way of writing:

\( 2 \) multiplied by \( x \), then subtract \( 3 \)

using algebraic convention?"
   },
  "answers": {
   "Answer_A": {
    "Answer_text": "\( 2(x-3) \)",
    "Misconception": "Does not account for grammar when writing algebra e.g. ,then making a group"
   },
   "Answer_B": {
    "Answer_text": "\( 2 \times x-3 \)",
    "Misconception": "Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions"
   },
   "Answer_C": {
    "Answer_text": "\( 2x-3 \)",
    "Misconception": "nan"
   },
   "Answer_D": {
    "Answer_text": "\( 3-2x \)",
    "Misconception": "nan"
   }
  },
  "Correct_Answer": "C"
 }
]

Misconception 358/1869:

```json
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify a transversal",

        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Parallel",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Perpendicular",
                "Misconception": "Believes any lines that cross are perpendicular"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Skew",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the term transversal"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "A transversal",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers",

            "Question": "If we want to write

        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x \times x \times x \times x \)",

                "Answer_text": "\( x^{4} \)",

        "Correct_Answer": "B"

Misconception 360/1869:
Here's another example based on the same misconceptions in the expected output format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data",
            "Subject": "Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data",
            "Question": "What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
1, 9, 3, 6, 8, 4
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes you don't need to numerically order the data before calculating the median"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes you don't need to numerically order the data before calculating the median"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 361/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "![Think of a number, then add \( 3 \), next multiply by \( 9 \), next subtract 2, and finally divide by \( 3 \).]() Maria says you can write this as:
\[
\frac{9(n+3)-2}{3}
\]
Tom says you can write this as:
\[
(9\times(n+3))-2\div 3
\]
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Maria",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Tom",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Maria and Tom",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 362/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c",
            "Subject": "Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation",
            "Question": "A line has equation \( 2 x+5 y=7 \)
What is it's gradient?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -2 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that for a line written in the form ax + by = c, a is the gradient"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -\frac{2}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{2}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 363/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Create a situation to match an algebraic expression",
            "Subject": "Writing Expressions",
            "Question": "Which model does not correctly represent the following expression?
\(3(2m+1)\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( m \) & \( m \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline\( m \) & \( m \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline\( m \) & \( m \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand bar modelling in algebra"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \( m \) & \( m \) & \( 1 \) & \( m \) & \( m \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand bar modelling in algebra"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \( m \) & \( m \) & \( m \) & \( m \) & \( m \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise the distributive property"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( m \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( m \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()",

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed",
            "Subject": "Rearranging Formula and Equations",
            "Question": "The formula for the speed of a car, \( S \), is \(S = \frac{D}{T}\), where \( D \) is the distance traveled and \( T \) is the time taken. Rearrange this to make the time taken, \( T \), the subject."

        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {

                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."

            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( T = \frac{D}{S} \)",

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",

            "Question": "Alex is trying to solve the equation on the right.

Which steps, if any, are correct? 
\[

\]

Step \( 2 \)
\[
2=a
\]]()"
        },

            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only step \( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not correctly simplify one-side variable equations"
            },

                "Answer_text": "Only step \( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes they must expand brackets before solving an equation"

                "Answer_text": "Both steps are correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Both steps are incorrect",

                "Misconception": "Believes dividing two positives will give a negative answer"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }

This new example maintains the same format and misconceptions as the original question. The correct answer is \( 3 \), since \( \frac{18}{6} = 3 \).

Misconception 389/1869:
Here is another example in the same format and misconceptions:

```json
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Match linear sequences to other representations, such as tables and graphs",
            "Subject": "Linear Sequences (nth term)",
            "Question": "![The first three terms of a sequence represented using dots. The first term is made of 2 dots, the second term has 3 dots and the third term has 4 dots.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline Position & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Term & \( 3 \) & \( \bigstar \) & \(  \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What value should replace the star?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the term in a sequence is double the position value"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Misconception 398/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Count backwards through zero starting from a positive integer",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers",

            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "Counts the starting number when counting backwards"
            },

                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not count end number when counting"

        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }

Misconception 399/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots",
            "Subject": "Substitution into Formula",
            "Question": "When \( g=5 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 g^{3}=50 \)
\( (2 g)^{3}=50 \)",
                "Misconception": "Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}2 g^{3}=250 \\ (2 g)^{3}=1000\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}2 g^{3}=1000 \\ (2 g)^{3}=1000\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies before applying a power "
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}2 g^{3}=1000 \\ (2 g)^{3}=50\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 400/1869:
### New Example in JSON format

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Round numbers to one decimal place",
            "Subject": "Rounding to Decimal Places",
            "Question": "\( 24.9876 \) to \( 1 \) decimal place is...."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 25.0 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 24.9 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds down instead of up"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 26.0 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 26.1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 401/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information",
            "Subject": "Venn Diagrams",
            "Question": "\( \begin{array}{c}\xi=\{\text { integers between } 1 \\ \text { and } 15 \text { inclusive }\} \\ P=\{\text { multiples of } 3\} \\ Q=\{\text { even numbers }\}\end{array} \) ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled P and Q. P without the intersection is labelled A, Q without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]() In which region does \( \mathbf{6} \) belong?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "A",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that the intersection of a Venn diagram represents those belonging to both sets"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "B",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "C",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that the intersection of a Venn diagram represents those belonging to both sets"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "D",
                "Misconception": "nan"

        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find missing angles using angles on a straight line",

        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 53^{\circ} \)",
```

Misconception 415/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not",
            "Subject": "Linear Sequences (nth term)",
            "Question": "Ava and Max are discussing the sequence \( \mathbf{9 n}-\mathbf{4} \)

Ava says \( \mathbf{2 0 3} \) is a term in the sequence.

Max says \( \mathbf{2 0 5} \) is a term in the sequence.

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ava",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Max",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Ava and Max",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

        "answers": {

Samantha",

Misconception 451/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given the description of an algebraic term with powers, write the term using algebra ",
            "Subject": "Writing Expressions",
            "Question": "Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( p \) multiplied by the square of \( q \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (p q)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Has not realised that the answer may be changed by the insertion of brackets"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( p q^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( p q+2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks cubing a number means adding 3 to that number"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 p q \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes cubing a number means you multiply it by 3"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
Note that for A, the issue remains of not recognizing brackets affect the answer.  B has no apparent issue yet is classified with nan.  C has been misaligned with an unrelated issue as it previously specifically mentioned cubing.  D mentions cubing as part of its reason, with unrelated text also present. As the details or the basis behind the generation is somewhat unclear/has issues then above follows in-line with it, but the clarity and relevance would to this extent remain poor so take caution and revise following a fixed revision of these points.

Misconception 457/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers",
            "Subject": "Ordering Fractions",
            "Question": "What fraction is the arrow pointing to? ![An image of a numberline with 6 dashes. On the leftmost dash is the number 0. On the middle dash is the number 1/2. On the rightmost dash is the number 1. An arrow points to the 4th dash from the left]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "When reading a dash on a number line does not take into account the number at the start or the width of each division"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{1}{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the arrow on a number line points to the middle value"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "There is no such fraction",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise you can use equivalent fractions to break fractions up into smaller divisions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

This new question features an image of a numberline with 6 dashes, ranging from 0 to 1. This makes the intervals slightly more complex to calculate, but by applying the same misconceptions to the answers, it still allows students to order fractions.

Misconception 458/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Convert ratios to fractions",
            "Subject": "Writing Ratios",
            "Question": "A fruit salad is made of apples and bananas in the ratio 4:5. What fraction of the salad is apples?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{9} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{5}{9} \)",
                "Misconception": "Gets order of ratio wrong"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Not enough information",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the relationship between a ratio and fraction"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 459/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Read values off an extension-time graph",
            "Subject": "Time Series and Line Graphs",
            "Question": "What was the extension of the spring at 4:30? ![A line graph with title "A graph to show the extension of a spring over time." 
The x-axis is titled "Time" and is labelled with times from 0400 to 0600 in steps of 1 hour, with the axis going half an hour beyond 0600.
The y-axis is titled "Extension of the spring (cm)" and the scale is from 0 to 20 in steps of 2cm. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0400, 0), (0415, 8), (0430, 10), (0450, 18), (0500, 18),(0520, 14),(0530, 10,), (0550, 4), (0600, 2).       
]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks a horizontal line on a time graph means an extension of 0"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 18 \mathrm{~mm} \)",
                "Misconception": "When reading values from graphs, writes down the wrong units"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 180 \mathrm{~mm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks there are 100mm and a cm"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1800 \mathrm{~mm} \)",
                "Misconception": ""
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    },
