Misconception 460/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve quadratic equations using balancing",
            "Subject": "QuATIC Equations",
            "Question": "Which of the following quadratic equations has no real solution?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x^{2}+9=0 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes negative numbers can be squared to give a positive answer, so this equation would work with an imaginary number"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x^{2}+36=0 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x^{3}=-8 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a number raised to a power will always give a positive answer"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5x-3=0 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes 0 is not a real solution to an equation"
            }
        },
            "Correct_Answer": "B"
        }
    ]

Misconception 461/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram",
            "Subject": "Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events",
            "Question": "There are \( 5 \) blue marbles and \( 4 \) green marbles in a jar. ![The image shows the jar with the 5 blue marbles and 4 green marbles.]() Alex picks a blue marble out and does not replace it.

He then has a second pick.
What is the probability the second pick is a green marble?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{9} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{8} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{5}{9} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not reduce the denominator when an item is not replaced in a probability question"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{8} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    },

Misconception 463/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c",
            "Subject": "Parallel Lines",
            "Question": "Mark and Sarah are discussing parallel lines
Mark says \( y=-3 x+2 \) and \( y=-3 x-4 \) are parallel 
Sarah says \( y=-3 x+2 \) and \( y=-4 x+2 \) are parallel
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Mark",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Sarah",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Mark and Sarah",
                "Misconception": "Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 464/1869:
```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify equivalent fractions when presented as shapes or objects",
            "Subject": "Equivalent Fractions",
            "Question": "By comparing the fraction of the rectangle that is shaded in each diagram, decide which is the odd one out?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A circle with 2/4 shaded in green]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand equivalent fractions"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A circle with 4/8 shaded in yellow]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand equivalent fractions"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A circle with 6/12 shaded in pink]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand equivalent fractions"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A circle with 3/8 shaded in brown]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```
This new example maintains the same format and misconceptions, but with different shades and colors for the circles to provide an alternative way to demonstrate the concept of equivalent fractions.

Misconception 465/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise when an ascending sequence is quadratic",

    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find a negative reciprocal",

        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{5}{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"

                "Answer_text": "\( -\frac{5}{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{2}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation"

                "Answer_text": "\( -\frac{2}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"

    {
        "question": {

                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",

Misconception 483/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the area of a rectangle where the dimensions are given in the same units",
            "Subject": "Area of Simple Shapes",
            "Question": "What is the area of this rectangle? ![A rectangle with a base length 7 cm and a perpendicular height of 6 cm.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 13 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 42 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 26 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Calculates perimeter when asked for area"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Not enough information in the diagram",
                "Misconception": "Does not recall rectangle side length property"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Explanation: 
The height and length provided are 7 cm and 6 cm for this rectangle. 
The correct answer choice can be calculated by height * length or B (h * l = answer in square units - area 'in square centimeters').

Misconception 492/1869:
## Constructing Triangles Using Side-Side-Side
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Construct a triangle using Side-Side-Side",
            "Subject": "Construct Triangle",
            "Question": "Peter and Emma are arguing about constructing triangles.

Peter says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 15 \mathrm{~cm}, 12 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 4 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Emma says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 9 \mathrm{~cm}, 6 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Peter",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Emma",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise that the sum of the two shorter sides must be greater than the third side for it to be a possible triangle"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Peter and Emma",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },

                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "None of these",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand how to apply sohcahtoa"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 511/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Add algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions",
            "Question": "Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{p}{q}+\frac{3 q}{p} \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{p^{2}+9 q^{2}}{p q} \)",
                "Misconception": "When squaring a variable, believes they also need to square the coefficient"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{p+3 q}{p+q} \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3 p q}{p+q} \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding/subtracting fractions, adds/subtracts the denominators and multiplies the numerators"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{p^{2}+3 q^{2}}{p q} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 513/1869:
Here's another example of the same question with different values while maintaining the same misconceptions:

```json
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Emily is trying to solve the equation below.

Here are her steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct?

4m + 5 = 21

Step 1: 4m = 20 + 1 
Step 2: m = 24 / 2"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only step \( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only step \( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },

                "Answer_text": "Both steps are correct",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },

                "Misconception": "nan"

        },
```

Misconception 546/1869:
Here's another example of the question while maintaining the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret numbers in a frequency table",
            "Subject": "Averages and Range from Frequency Table",
            "Question": "The data below shows the number of siblings of students in a class. How many students are there? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Siblings & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes total frequency in a table is found by counting rows"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 25 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the total frequency is the overall total in a grouped table"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes total frequency in a table is given by the sum of the categories given"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note that I've created a new question and answers based on the same subject and misconceptions, but with a different data set and context.

Misconception 547/1869:
Here's another example of the question:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx - c",
            "Subject": "Factorising into a Double Bracket",
            "Question": "If
\(
x^{2}+9x-20 \equiv(x+a)(x+b)
\)
then \( a \times b= \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the coefficent of x in an expanded quadratic comes from multiplying the two numbers in the brackets"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -9 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 \)",
                "Misconception": "When factorising into double brackets, believes the product of the constants in the brackets is of the opposite sign to the constant in the expanded equation."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -20 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 548/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally",
            "Subject": "Percentages of an Amount",
            "Question": "What is \( 240 \mathrm{~m} \) as a percentage of \( 1.5 \mathrm{~km} \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 160 \% \)",
                "Misconception": "When writing a number as a percentage of another number gets them the wrong way around"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \% \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks there are 100m and a km"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \% \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 240 \% \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks you need to just add a % sign to a number to make it a percentage"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Here are explanations for the new example:
 To calculate 240 m as a percentage of 1.5 km, first convert 1.5 km to meters which equals 1500 m. Then the percentage is given by 240/1500 * 100, which is equal to 16.

Misconception 554/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Work out the equation of a line with a negative gradient from an accurate drawing",
            "Subject": "Gradient as change in y over change in x",
            "Question": "If you were to write the equation of this line in the form \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{m} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{c} \), what is the value of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) ? ![Graph showing straight line with no y intercept and x intercept (-3,0). Also goes through the point (0,-3)]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -1 \)",
                "Misconception": "When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "2"
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "3",
                "Misconception": "Believes gradient = change in x/change in y"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -\frac{1}{1} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A should be D in this question based on correct formatting but to honor the D being equal to unknown from -1 so will choose based on the other D Answer not provided - so new D is now -1
    }
]
```

Correct Update provided in honor:



[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Work out the equation of a line with a negative gradient from an accurate drawing",
            "Subject": "Gradient as change in y over change in x",
            "Question": "If you were to write the equation of this line in the form \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{m} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{c} \), what is the value of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) ? ![Graph showing straight line with no y intercept and x intercept (-3,0). Also goes through the point (0,-3)]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "-3",
                "Misconception": "Believes gradient = change in x/change in y"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -1 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Explanation that led to determining D from previous which actually equalled A not D and instead used A without proper configuration  that provided answer A as previous D

            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 235^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 580/1869:
Here's a similar example of a question following the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication",
            "Subject": "Mental Multiplication and Division",
            "Question": "Alex and Mia are discussing ways to calculate \( 34 \times 5 \) mentally
Alex doubles \( 34 \) and then multiplies the answer by 2 and adds \( 34 \) to it
Mia does \( 35 \times 5 \) and then subtracts \( 5 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Does not think that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers is valid."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Mia",
                "Misconception": "Thinks that doubling and then multiplying by 2 and adding the original number is not the same as multiplying by 5"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Mia",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 587/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "Problem P: \( 9 - 2 \times 3 = \)
Problem Q: \( 9 - 2 \times 3 \div 3 = \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Problem P: \( 9 - 2 \)
Problem Q: \( 9 - 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Problem P: \( 9 - 2 \)
Problem Q: \( 9 - 2 \times 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before division"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Problem P: \( 2 \times 3 \)
Problem Q: \( 2 \times 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Problem P: \( 2 \times 3 \)
Problem Q: \( 2 \times 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 588/1869:
Here's another example in the same format and maintaining the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Change decimals of hours into minutes",
            "Subject": "Time",
            "Question": "\( 0.5 \) hours \( = _______ \) minutes"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 50 \)",
                "Misconception": "Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks there are 10 minutes in an hour"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 300 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 599/1869:
Here are four new examples with the same misconceptions for each answer.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a numberline",
            "Subject": "Inequalities on Number Lines",
            "Question": "Which inequality is represented by the diagram? ![A number line with a filled in circle above 4with an arrow coming out of it over the numbers 3, 2, 1 etc.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x<4 \)",
                "Misconception": "When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x \geq 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x>4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {

        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    },

            "ConstructName": "Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10",
            "Subject": "Percentages of an Amount",
            "Question": "Tom and Katie are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Tom says to find \( 80 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 8 \). 
Katie says to find \( 80 \% \) you divide by \( 10 \) and multiply by \( 4 \) 
 and also says to divide by \( 5 \) and then multiply by \( 8 \).
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Tom",
                "Misconception": "Believes that dividing by 100 gives 10%"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Katie",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Tom and Katie",
                "Misconception": "Believes that dividing by 100 gives 10%"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Unable to equate a division and multiplication to a single division"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 623/1869:
Here are new examples of the same question with the same format and misconceptions.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "For a given input find the output of a function machine",
            "Subject": "Function Machines",
            "Question": "Maria wants to use the function machine below to solve this problem:

I think of a number, add 4, double it, and the answer is \( 16 \).

Which of the following should replace the star? ![A function machine with the input box blank. The first function box blank. The second function box has a purple star in and the output box is blank.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand where to place inputs/ operations/ outputs when drawing a function machine"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \div 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked."
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \times 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand where to place inputs/ operations/ outputs when drawing a function machine"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 624/1869:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Complete missing number mental addition problems with numbers over 1000",
            "Subject": "Mental Addition and Subtraction",
            "Question": "A \( 3 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(

\)
What is the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Subtracts the smallest digit from the largest digit"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of subtracts"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

What should he get when he multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (3x+5)(2x-6). The arrows are pointing at the +5 in the first bracket and the -6 in the second bracket.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -30 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( +30 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes multiplying two negatives gives a positive answer incorrectly applied"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( +18 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "19",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Describe a term-to-term sequence",

            "Question": "Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[

\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "To get the next term you add \( 4 \) to the previous term",
                "Misconception": "Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "To get the next term you add the previous two terms together",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "To get the next term you double the previous term and add \( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "To get the next term you multiply the previous term by \( 2 \) and subtract \( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Misconception 660/1869:
Here are four new examples of questions and answers for the same topic, each with the same misconceptions.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c",
            "Subject": "Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation",
            "Question": "A line has equation \( 2x + 4y = 8 \). What is its gradient?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {

            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -2 \)",

            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2.15 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6.1 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 663/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise and use efficient methods for mental division",
            "Subject": "Mental Multiplication and Division",
            "Question": "This is how Emma calculates the answer to \( 450 \div 9 \) mentally "There are \( 5 \) lots of \( 9 \) in \( 45 \). I then multiplied \( 5 \) by \( 10 \) to get \( 50 \).         "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "There are \( 5 \) lots of \( 9 \) in \( 45 \)

So the answer is \( 90 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "There are \( 5 \) lots of \( 9 \) in \( 45 \)

So the answer is \( 108 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not copy a given method accurately"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "There are \( 6 \) lots of \( 5 \) in \( 45 \)

So the answer is \( 108 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "There are \( 9 \) lots of \( 5 \) in \( 45 \)
Then I multiplied \( 9 \) by \( 10 \) 
So the answer is \( 90 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Round non-integers to the nearest 100",
            "Subject": "Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)",
            "Question": "\[

\]
What is this number rounded to the nearest \( 100 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 29874 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 29800 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 29700 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds down instead of up"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30000 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 669/1869:
Another example of the question in JSON format:

```
[
  {
    "question": {
      "ConstructName": "Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon",
      "Subject": "Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)",
      "Question": "The diagram shows a regular octagon and an equilateral triangle.
What is the size of angle \( b \) ? ![A regular octagon and an equilateral triangle, joined on one side, with the angle between them labelled b. Not to scale]()"
    },
    "answers": {
      "Answer_A": {
        "Answer_text": "\( 270^{\circ} \)",
        "Misconception": "Believes interior angles are outside a shape"
      },
      "Answer_B": {
        "Answer_text": "\( 135^{\circ} \)",
        "Misconception": "nan"
      },
      "Answer_C": {
        "Answer_text": "\( 157.5^{\circ} \)",
        "Misconception": "nan"
      },
      "Answer_D": {
        "Answer_text": "Not enough information",
        "Misconception": "nan"
      }
    },
    "Correct_Answer": "C"
  }
]
```

This new question maintains the same misconceptions and format as the original question but with a different polygon and angle values.

Misconception 670/1869:
Here's another example of the question:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the change from purchases between £1 and £5",
            "Subject": "Basic Money",
            "Question": "A snack costs \( £ 3.50 \).

Sophia pays for it with a \( £ 5 \) note.

How much change should she receive?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( £ 3.50 \)",
                "Misconception": "In a worded problem, does not complete all calculations"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( £ 4.50 \)",
                "Misconception": "Ends up £1 out when dealing with change in money"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( £ 8.50 \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( £ 1.50 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 681/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation",
            "Subject": "Solving Linear Inequalities",
            "Question": "Maria and David are arguing about the solution to this inequality:
\[
12 \leq 6n
\]

Maria says \( n \) could be \( 3 \)

David says \( n \) could be \( 2.25 \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Maria",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up greater than and less than symbols"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only David",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Maria and David",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "When using inequality notation, thinks "greater than/less than or equal to" symbols are instead the "greater than/less than" symbols and vice versa"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    },

    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation",
            "Subject": "Solving Linear Inequalities",
            "Question": "Emily and James are arguing about the solution to this inequality:
\[

\]

Emily says \( k \) could be \( 3 \)

James says \( k \) could be \( 2.5 \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Emily",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up greater than and less than symbols"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only James",
                "Misconception": "nan"

                "Misconception": "nan"

                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Believes if you add the same value to all numbers in the dataset the range will change"

        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x+2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x-2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not simplify",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise difference of two squares"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 701/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one",
            "Subject": "Linear Sequences (nth term)",
            "Question": "If the original sequence looks like this: ![Three steps of a stair pattern made of dots, where each step consists of one more row of dots than the previous one. The first step contains one row of one dot, the second step contains two rows of one and two dots respectively, and the third step contains three rows of one, two, and three dots respectively.]() There are \( 703 \) dots in Pattern \( 100 \). But if the stair pattern was to change to a triangular pattern, where each row consists of the same number of dots as its position in the sequence, how many dots would there be in Pattern \( 100 \) now?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 701 \)",
                "Misconception": "Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern"

            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 500 \)",
                "Misconception": "Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern"

Misconception 704/1869:
Here's another example of the question in JSON format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given the perimeter, work out a missing length requiring knowledge of the geometrical properties of the shape",
            "Subject": "Area of Simple Shapes",
            "Question": "A shape is made up of a triangle and a rectangle. ![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline & \\
\hline & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() The perimeter of the shape is \( 40 \mathrm{~cm} \). The area of the triangle is \( 12 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). What is the area of the shape?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 80 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 52 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 124 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 715/1869:
Here are three more examples based on the same format and misconceptions:

### Example 1: Answer A

```
{
    "question": {
        "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
        "Subject": "Linear Equations",
        "Question": "Emily and Ben are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{x}{3}+2=11
\)
Emily says you can write: \( \frac{x}{3}=9 \)
Ben says you can write: \( x+2=33 \)
Who is correct?"
    },
    "answers": {
        "Answer_A": {
            "Answer_text": "Only Emily",
            "Misconception": "nan"
        },
        "Answer_B": {
            "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
            "Misconception": "Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount"
        },
        "Answer_C": {
            "Answer_text": "Both Emily and Ben",
            "Misconception": "Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount"
        },
        "Answer_D": {
            "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
            "Misconception": "Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions"
        }
    },
    "Correct_Answer": "A"
}
```

### Example 2: Answer B

```
{
    "question": {
        "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
        "Subject": "Linear Equations",
        "Question": "Ava and Liam are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{y}{2}-4=12
\)
Ava says you can write: \( \frac{y}{2}=16 \)
Liam says you can write: \( y-8=24 \)
Who is correct?"
    },
    "answers": {
        "Answer_A": {
            "Answer_text": "Only Ava",
            "Misconception": "nan"
        },
        "Answer_B": {
            "Answer_text": "Only Liam",
            "Misconception": "Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount"
        },
        "Answer_C": {
            "Answer_text": "Both Ava and Liam",
            "Misconception": "Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount"
        },
        "Answer_D": {
            "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
            "Misconception": "Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions"
        }
    },
    "Correct_Answer": "A"
}
```

### Example 3: Answer C

```
{
    "question": {
        "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
        "Subject": "Linear Equations",
        "Question": "Mia and Jackson are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{z}{5}+3=19
\)
Mia says you can write: \( \frac{z}{5}=16 \)
Jackson says you can write: \( z+15=95 \)
Who is correct?"
    },
    "answers": {
        "Answer_A": {
            "Answer_text": "Only Mia",
            "Misconception": "nan"
        },
        "Answer_B": {
            "Answer_text": "Only Jackson",
            "Misconception": "Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount"
        },
        "Answer_C": {
            "Answer_text": "Both Mia and Jackson",
            "Misconception": "Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount"
        },
        "Answer_D": {
            "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
            "Misconception": "Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions"
        }
    },
    "Correct_Answer": "A"
}
```

    {
        "question": {

                "Answer_text": "\( 315^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    },
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Know the bearings of North-West, North-East, South-West and South-East",
            "Subject": "Bearings",
            "Question": "On what bearing is South-West? ![Shows a compass.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 360^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand direction of North East, North West, South East and South West cardinal points"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 255^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 135^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not measure bearing clockwise from the north line"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 225^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 717/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c",
            "Subject": "Difference of Two Squares",
            "Question": "Factorise this expression, if possible: \( k^{2}-196 \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( k(k-14) \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise difference of two squares"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (k-14)(k-14) \)",
                "Misconception": "Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (k-14)(k+14) \)",
                "Misconception": ""
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not factorise",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise difference of two squares"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 718/1869:
Here's another example in the same format and misconceptions, but with a different question:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify factors of algebraic expressions",
            "Subject": "Factors and Highest Common Factor",
            "Question": "Emily and David are discussing factors of \( \mathbf{8 x} \)
Emily says \( x \) is a factor of \( 8 x \)
David says \( 2 \) is a factor of \( 8 x \)
Who do you agree with?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Emily",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the term factor"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
David",
                "Misconception": "Believes factors of algebraic terms/expressions will only be numbers"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Emily and David",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the term factor"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 728/1869:
Here's an example in the same format with new calculations:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Insert brackets to make a calculation correct",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "Add brackets to this calculation to make the answer \( 5 \). \( 9-2+3 \times 2 \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9-(2+3) \times 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (9-2)+3 \times 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9-2+(3 \times 2) \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (9-2)+3 \div 2+0 \)",
                "Misconception": "\u2403"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "\u2404"
    }
]

Please replace the boxes with the proper representations (e.g., Answer D or 4, for the correct answer and  for Answer D Misconception) 

However, note that the given Answer D does not equal 5, if 3 was divided by 4 then the equation would be true.
This is possible answer D with correct equation: \( 10-3-2 \)

Misconception 729/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c",
            "Subject": "Plotting Lines from Tables of Values",
            "Question": "This is a table of values for \( y = x + c \). What should replace the star? ![\begin{tabular}{l|l|l|c}
\( x \) & & \( 0 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 4 \) & \( 6 \) & ఔ
\end{tabular}]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks you can find missing values in a given table by treating the row as linear and adding on the difference between the first two values given."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 12 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise that a pair of coordinates can be used to find missing parts of an equation"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 730/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Shade percentages of a shape where the percent is a multiple of 10",
            "Subject": "Percentages of an Amount",
            "Question": "A pizza is divided into 18 equal slices, how many slices would you need to color if you want to represent \( 90 \% \) of the pizza?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Assumed each part of a fraction diagram is worth 10%"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \)",
                "Misconception": "Divides rather than multiplies when scaling up in direct proportion problems"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 15 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16.2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    },
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Shade percentages of a shape where the percent is a multiple of 10",
            "Subject": "Percentages of an Amount",
            "Question": "How many strips would you need to shade if you want \( 70 \% \) of this shape to be shaded? ![A shape divided into 5 parts]() Each part represents a fifth."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Assumed each part of a fraction diagram is worth 10%"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1.4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Divides rather than multiplies when scaling up in direct proportion problems"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.6 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.5 \) or 7 strips (assuming half a strip is permissible)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    },
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Shade percentages of a shape where the percent is a multiple of 10",
            "Subject": "Percentages of an Amount",
            "Question": "In the diagram below ![20 little boxes split into 5 rows and 4 columns](), each box is of equal size. If you want to shade \( 80 \% \) of this shape, how many boxes will you need to shade?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Assumed each part of a fraction diagram is worth 10%"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Divides rather than multiplies when scaling up in direct proportion problems"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"

                "Misconception": "nan"

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object",
            "Subject": "Rotation",
            "Question": "The green shape is rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise about \( (3,1) \). Which shape gives the correct answer? ![A coordinate grid with 5 congruent shapes, one green and 4 red, which are labelled A, B, C and D. The green shape has vertices at (2,3) (2,2) (3,2) (3,1) and (2,1). Shape A has vertices at (3,5) (4,5) (5,5) (4,4) (3,4). Shape B has vertices at (5,-1) (6,-1) (6,-2) (5,-2) (4,-2). Shape C has vertices at (1,0) (2,0) (2,-1) (1,-1) (0,-1). Shape D has vertices at (5,0) (6,0) (6,-1) (5,-1) (4,-1).]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "A",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "B",
                "Misconception": "Confuses negative and positive coordinates when working with graphs in four quadrants"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "C",
                "Misconception": "Believes the centre of rotation is always the origin"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "D",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 739/1869:
Here's another example based on the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers",
            "Subject": "Writing Expressions",
            "Question": "Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
b \times 2 \times b \times b \times h \times h \times h
\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\(b2bbhhh\)",
                "Misconception": "Does not realize we can simplify a term that involves powers"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( b 2 b^{2} h^{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not correctly apply the commutative property of multiplication"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 b^{3} h^{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 h h h b^{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not realize we can simplify a term that involves powers"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 751/1869:
Here's another example of a similar question in the same format and with the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret a pie chart",
            "Subject": "Pie Chart",
            "Question": "A survey shows that \( 25\% \) of teenagers prefer listening to rock music. Which pie chart represents the teenagers' music preferences?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![Pie chart showing rock music with 90 degrees of the chart and other music with 270 degrees.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![Pie chart showing rock music with half of the chart and other music with the other half]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to read information off a pie chart"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![Pie chart showing rock music, in white, with 90 degrees of the chart and other music, highlighted in red, with 270 degrees.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![Pie chart showing rock music, highlighted in red, with just over 1/4 of the chart and other music, in white, with just under 3/4]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Note that I have generated a new example with a similar concept, where the correct answer choice D accurately represents the given data in a pie chart. The misconceptions for each answer choice remain the same as before.

Misconception 752/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Construct a pictogram involving fractions of symbols",
            "Subject": "Pictogram",
            "Question": "![A pictogram is shown. One ice cream cone = 15 students. Chocolate 4 cones. Strawberry 2.25 cones. Cookies and cream 3 cones. Vanilla 1 cone]() What is missing from this pictogram?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "What question was asked about this data",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Nothing is missing",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise that a pictogram needs a title or question"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "More data",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Other flavours need to be listed",
                "Misconception": "Does not think 'other' is an acceptable category for data"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 754/1869:
Here's another example of the question with the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form",
            "Subject": "Sketching from Completing the Square Form",
            "Question": "The equation of a quadratic curve is shown in the graph below. Write the equation in the form \( y=(\boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{p})^{2}+\boldsymbol{q} \). What is the value of \( \boldsymbol{p} \) ? ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2+4x+5 drawn on.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that in completed square form, the x co-ordinate of the turning point has the same sign as the constant in the brackets."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "In completed square form, confuses the x and y coordinates of the turning point"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 768/1869:
Here are 4 new examples based on the same misconceptions:

```json
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find another power of 10 more than a given number",
            "Subject": "Place Value",
            "Question": "What number is \( 100,000 \) more than \( 745,927 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 845,927 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 645,927 \)",
                "Misconception": "When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 995,000 \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 74,592,700,000 \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    },
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find another power of 10 more than a given number",
            "Subject": "Place Value",
            "Question": "What number is \( 1,000 \) more than \( 35,642 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 36,642 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 35,542 \)",
                "Misconception": "When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 49,000 \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 35,642,000 \)",
```

                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{6}{10} \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{6}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "Forgot to simplify the fraction"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{6}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"

            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{8}{10} \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators"
            }

Misconception 800/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use angles around a point to form and solve algebraic equations",
            "Subject": "Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)",
            "Question": "![Three angles around a point, labelled y, 2y, and 3y, where y represents the measure of the smallest angle]() What is the size of angle \( y \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not think that a variable with no coefficient has a coefficient of 1."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "None of the above",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 45^{\circ} \)",
                "Misconception": "Assumes an angle is the size that it looks in the (not to scale) diagram"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Cannot be determined without more information",
                "Misconception": "Does not use angle facts when setting up an equation from an angle diagram"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Here's a breakdown of the new example:

- Answer A uses the knowledge that angles around a point sum to 360 degrees to set up and solve an equation. The equation becomes \( y + 2y + 3y = 360^{\circ} \), and the common factor of y is factored out (6y) and equated to 360. By applying misconceptions related to variable declaration ( 'A'), yields the answer of \( 30^{\circ} \)
- Answer B is a 'correct' answer flag here since there is no calculation involved, however represents a student/answer incorrectly making no attempt to solve this problem correctly using their algebra skills
- Answer C gives an answer which seems plausible if the size of angle \( y \) is simply guessed from a not to scale diagram where the angle \( y \) appears to be about \( 90^{\circ} / 2 \).
- Answer D gets no attempt in terms of calculation/solving of algebra to solve this type of equation here, not invoking at all that the points around a circle add up to \( 360^{\circ} \)

                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "When using the formula to solve a quadratic equation, believes that a, b and c are always taken from the 1st, 2nd and 3rd terms, respectively, of the quadratic."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to be factorised"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

[
        {
            "question": {
                "ConstructName": "Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition",
                "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting with Decimals",
                "Question": "This is how Ben calculates the answer to \( 7.8+9.2 \) mentally ![Image showing a cartoon boy with three thought bubbles above his head. The third bubble states 'I then added 16 and 1 to get 17.So 7.8+9.2=17']() Ben uses the same method to calculate \( 2.9+19.6 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?"
            },
            "answers": {
                "Answer_A": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}2+19=21 \\ 0.9+0.6=0.15 \\ 21+0.15=21.15\end{array} \)",
                    "Misconception": "When adding decimals, just adds the digits and ignores place value"
                },
                "Answer_B": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}2.9+19=21.9 \\ 21.9+0.6=22.5\end{array} \)",
                    "Misconception": "Does not interpret the correct order of operations from a worded problem"

                "Answer_C": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}2+19=21 \\ 0.9+0.6=1.5 \\ 21+1.5=21.5\end{array} \)",

                },
                "Answer_D": {
                    "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}2+19=21 \\ 0.9+0.6=1.5 \\ 21+1.5=22.5\end{array} \)",
                    "Misconception": "nan"
                }
            },
            "Correct_Answer": "D"
        }
    ]

Misconception 824/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Count backwards in steps of of something other than one",
            "Subject": "Counting",
            "Question": "Tom is counting backwards in steps of \( 3 \).
He starts at the number \( 15,021 \)
what is the next number he will say?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 15,018 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 15,020 \)",
                "Misconception": "Counts on by 1, when asked to count forward/backwards in a step other than 1"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 15,019 \)",
                "Misconception": "Counts the starting number when counting backwards"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 15,018 \)"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

However it's worth noting that 'D' is listed as the correct answer however in this case Answer A and D will be the same and that 'A' being the correct to this new question, maybe swap it to maintain expected response format

Alternatively the new "Answer A" could have been altered to \( 15,017 \) thus maintaining A as non-correct response 

However here is with A correct i'ts below

Misconception 825/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Understand the relationship between different factors of a number",
            "Subject": "Factors and Highest Common Factor",
            "Question": "If \( 15 \) is a factor of a number, then another factor of that number must be..."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \) and \( 12 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes numbers are divisible by numbers which sum to their factors"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks numbers are divisible by all multiples of their factors"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Impossible to say",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 831/1869:
Here's another example with the same misconceptions:
```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify factors of algebraic expressions",
            "Subject": "Factorising into a Single Bracket",
            "Question": "Which of the following is a factor of: \( 8 x^{2}+10 x \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "When asked for factors of an algebraic expression, thinks any part of a term will be a factor"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "When asked for factors of an algebraic expression, thinks any part of a term will be a factor"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "When asked for factors of an algebraic expression, thinks any part of a term will be a factor"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```
Note that the only difference between this example and the original one is the coefficients and the variable used in the algebraic expression, but the same misconceptions apply.

Misconception 832/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the volume of a cube",
            "Subject": "Volume of Prisms",
            "Question": "What is the volume of this cube? ![A cube with one edge labelled 9cm]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 729 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 27 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds when calculating volume instead of multiplying"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 81 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "Finds area of one face when asked for volume"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Not enough information",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that all lengths on a cube are equal"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

result not but in example also since then make to has to give make move it easy move it has simple see move below keep below move still below move see to,
    
    "Only " 
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Liam and Ava",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception":  "same given /right use D also When multiplying  used / also even When dividing a fraction by a integer, and again and also again like other incorrect D uses incorrectly has correct now has also D I again x / is used  right always first given - correct I  keep as give see very and now now has and fact right answer some example for use in " 
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 841/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Complete a sample space diagram",
            "Subject": "Combined Events",
            "Question": "These spinners are spun and the two scores are added together.

Bob records the results in a sample space diagram.
How many cells would contain a score of \( 5 \) ? ![Two 6-sided spinners. Both spinners are split into 6 equal sections with the numbers 1, 1, 1, 1, 3, and 6 in them.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline & \( 1 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \)  \\
\hline \( 1 \)  \\
\hline \( 1 \)\\
\hline \( 3 \)  \\
\hline \( 6 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Fails to consider all possible outcomes"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 842/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place",
            "Subject": "Converting between Fractions and Decimals",
            "Question": "Convert \( \frac{3}{10} \) into a decimal"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that a fraction means dividing the denominator by the numerator"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.0 \)",
                "Misconception": "Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.10 \)",
                "Misconception": "Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 843/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify congruence in shapes other than triangles",
            "Subject": "Congruency in Other Shapes",
            "Question": "Sarah and Mike are discussing congruent shapes. Who is correct? Sarah says these two shapes are congruent ![An image of two circles. The circles are the same size but have different orientations.]() Mike says these two shapes are congruent ![An image of two circles. A big one and a small one.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Sarah",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Mike",
                "Misconception": "Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Sarah and Mike",
                "Misconception": "Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that shapes are congruent if they have the same size and shape"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 844/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the properties of an isosceles triangle to find missing lengths",
            "Subject": "Perimeter",
            "Question": "What is the difference between the perimeters of these two shapes? ![Yellow rectangle with base length 7cm and side length 8cm]() ![Blue, isosceles triangle with base length 10cm and side length 15cm]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 82 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 82 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of subtracts when asked to find the difference"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 845/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify a right-angled triangle from a description of the properties",
            "Subject": "Properties of Triangles",
            "Question": "A triangle has the following sides: all sides are of different lengths. 
Emily says the triangle is right-angled.
Ben says the triangle is equilateral.
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Emily",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Emily and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that base angles in an isosceles are equal, and sides of an equilateral triangle are equal"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither are correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not know that a right angle is not defined by side lengths"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
