Misconception 847/1869:
Here's another example of a question with the same format and misconceptions.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)",
            "Subject": "Factorising into a Single Bracket",
            "Question": "Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-5 p
\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (p-5)(p+5) \)",
                "Misconception": "When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( p(p-5) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (p-5)(p-5) \)",
                "Misconception": "When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not
factorise",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 848/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use prime factor decomposition to find the Lowest Common Multiple of two numbers",
            "Subject": "Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple",
            "Question": "Here is the completed Venn diagram from earlier in the quiz.
What calculation works out the lowest common multiple of \( 50 \) and \( 80 \) ? ![A Venn diagram showing the Prime factors of 50 set and the Prime factors of 80 set. There are no 5's in the prime factors of 50 and is visible 4, 5 and 8's in the intersecting set as well as an additional 5 in the prime factors of 50 set,  and additional 5 in the prime factors of 50 set.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \times 2 \times 2 \times 5 \times 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \times 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the calculations for HCF and LCM"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \times 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "forgets to include the common factors when calculating the lowest common multiple"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \times 2 \times 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

                "Answer_text": "\( 551 \)",
                "Misconception": "When finding the value of a number given in roman numerals, adds the value of all letters together without considering the position of the letter."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 561 \)",
                "Misconception": "When finding the value of a number given in roman numerals, adds the value of all letters together without considering the position of the letter."

            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 551 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 651 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }

Misconception 861/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret numbers in a frequency table",
            "Subject": "Averages and Range from Frequency Table",
            "Question": "\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Cars & Frequency & Cars \( \times \) Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} The table shows the numbers of cars in the households of students in a class.

What does the "10" represent?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "How many families who own the \( 5 \) vehicles",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "The total number of cars in all \( 5 \) households",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the variable and frequency columns in a frequency table"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "The average number of cars in the \( 5 \) households",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the interpretation of the fx column in a frequency table"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "The total number of cars in the \( 5 \) households",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 881/1869:
Here is the expected output in JSON:

 [
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find the nth term rule for an ascending integer linear sequence",
            "Subject": "Linear Sequences (nth term)",
            "Question": "Here are the first five terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llllll}1 & 4 & 7 & 10 & 13 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 n \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Add \( 3 \) to the previous term",
                "Misconception": "Believes nth term rule can be given in words"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 n-2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Triple, add one",
                "Misconception": "Believes nth term rule can be given in words"
            },
            "Answer_E": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \}",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the nth term is constant"
            },
            "Answer_F": {
                "Answer_text": "4Add triple the term number minus 1",
                "Misconception": "Thinks there is more than one type of sequence that needs to be entered in the box for nth term"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

    ConstructName: Find the nth term rule for an ascending integer linear sequence
    ###
    Subject: Linear Sequences (nth term)
    ###
    Question: Here are the first five terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llllll}1 & 4 & 7 & 10 & 13 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.

    ###
    Answer A: \( 3 n \)
    Answer A Misconception: Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion
    Answer B: Add \( 3 \) to the previous term
    Answer B Misconception: Believes nth term rule can be given in words
    Answer C: \( 3 n-2 \)
    Answer C Misconception: nan
    Answer D: Triple, add one
    Answer D Misconception: Believes nth term rule can be given in words
    Answer E: \( 3 \)
    Answer E Misconception: Thinks the nth term is constant
    Answer F: 4 tripled term number minus 1
    Answer F Misconception: Thinks there is more than one type of sequence that needs to be entered in the box for nth term

\[
4x+5y=30
\] Who has written a related linear equation?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand how to create a multiple of an equation"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 899/1869:

    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division",

            "Question": "\[

\]

        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9-2 \)",

            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5+3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },

                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \times 9 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "It doesn't matter: you get the same answer",

        "Correct_Answer": "C"

Here's another example based on the same misconception:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = 0",
            "Subject": "Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations",
            "Question": "This is a graph of
\(y=2-0.2 x\) ![A set of axes with y=2-0.2x drawn on.]() Use the graph to solve
\(2-0.2 x=0\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=10 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=0 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the solution of mx + c = 0 is x =0"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes they solve mx + c = 0 by substituting in x = 0"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=-0.2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the solution of mx + c = 0 is x = m"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

Misconception 909/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline",
            "Subject": "Inequalities on Number Lines",
            "Question": "Which number line represents \( 2 < x \leq 6 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![Number line with numbers from -5 to 5 to 10. Above the 2 is an open, unfilled circle with an arrow to the right. Above the 6 is an open, unfilled circle with an arrow to the left.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![Number line with numbers from -5 to 5 to 10. Above the 2 is an open, unfilled circle with an arrow to the left. Above the 6 is a red, filled circle with an arrow to the right.]()",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up greater than and less than symbols"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![Number line with numbers from -5 to 5 to 10. Above the 2 is a blue, filled circle and above the 6 is an open, unfilled circle. The two circles are joined by a horizontal line.]()",
                "Misconception": "When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![Number line with numbers from -5 to 5 to 10. Above the 2 is an open, unfilled circle and above the 6 is a green, filled circle. The two circles are joined by a horizontal line.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 916/1869:
Here's another example based on the same misconception for each answer provided:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure",
            "Subject": "Rounding to Decimal Places",
            "Question": "Samantha and Alex are arguing about rounding.

Samantha says \( \mathbf{4 9 9 . 7 2} \) rounded to \( 1 \) significant figure is \( \mathbf{5 0 0} \)

Alex says \( \mathbf{4 9 9 . 7 2} \) rounded to \( 1 \) decimal place is \( \mathbf{5 0 0} \)
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Samantha",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Samantha and Alex",
                "Misconception": "When rounding to decimal places and the only digits after the decimal point will be zeros, just gives the integer as the answer."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 917/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed",
            "Subject": "Rearranging Formula and Equations",
            "Question": "Alex and Mia are discussing rearranging \( y=\frac{a}{b+2} \) to make \( b \) the subject
Alex says a correct first line of working could be: \( y=\frac{a}{b}+2 \)
Mia says a correct first line of working could be: \( y(b+2)=a \)
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Thinks that the fraction of an expression divides each term in the expression, rather than dividing the whole expression"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Mia",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Mia",
                "Misconception": "Thinks that the fraction of an expression divides each term in the expression, rather than dividing the whole expression"
            },
            "Answer_D": {

Misconception 934/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c",
            "Subject": "Plotting Lines from Tables of Values",
            "Question": "\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) &   
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( 3 x+ y=7 \) 
What should replace the star?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 21 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes 0 multiplied by a number gives the number"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6.7 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up the value of two terms when substituting"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 935/1869:
Here's another example with the same format and misconceptions:

```json
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Substitute a solution back into the remaining equation and find the second solution",
            "Subject": "Simultaneous Equations",
            "Question": "Samantha is solving a pair of simultaneous equations, one of which is below.

\(
5 t + r = 15
\)

Samantha found that \( r = 5 \)
What does \( t \) equal?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( t = -6 / 5 = -2 \) then forgot the minus sign \( t = 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes dividing a negative by a positive gives a positive answer"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( t = 5 + 5 = t = 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "Ignores the negative signs when adding positive and negative numbers"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 t = 15 + 5 = 5 t = 20 \) then \( 5 t + t = 20 + t \), cancel out and end up with an incorrect solution \( t = -20 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 t = 15 - 5 = 5 t = 10 \), \( t = 2 \), \( t = 2 \) doesn't feel right so \( t = 10 / 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

            "Question": "Tom and Alex are discussing this sequence. ![The first 3 patterns in a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a triangle with 3 coloured dots along each side. 
Pattern 2 is made up of 2 triangles joined at a common vertex. There are also 6 coloured dots along the perimeter of this pattern. 
Pattern 3 is made up of 3 triangles joined at a common vertex. There are also 9 coloured dots along the perimeter of this pattern.]() Tom says the number of triangles in the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) term will be double the number of triangles in the \( 2^{\text {nd }} \) term.

Misconception 945/1869:
Here's an example of another question with the same format and misconceptions for each answer:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation",
            "Subject": "Estimation",
            "Question": "Leah and Ryan are discussing using estimation when multiplying
Leah says \( 93 \times 2>190 \)
Ryan says \( 59 \times 6<350 \)
Without calculating the exact answers, who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Leah",
                "Misconception": "Believes rounding numbers down would give an overestimate"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ryan",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Leah and Ryan",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```

In this example, Ryan's statement (\( 59 \times 6>350 \)) seems more likely to be inaccurate as \( 60 \times 6 = 360 \), which is greater than 350.  Leah's statement (\( 93 \times 2>190 \)) seems more likely to be correct as \( 93 \times 2 = 186 \),  \( 90 \times 2 = 180 \) is less than 180 but \( 100 \times 2 = 200 \)  would be more than 190, it does have some mathematical inaccuracy, without exact calculation however we lean towards Ryan's estimation as more incorrect and Leah's possible but less probable.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Sort and class quadrilaterals into hierarchical families",
            "Subject": "Properties of Quadrilaterals",
            "Question": "Sofia and Alex are discussing this shape
Sofia says it is an oblong
Alex says it is a rectangle
Who do you agree with? ![Rectangle with right angles labelled]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Sofia",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Does not remember that an oblong has all right angles"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Sofia and Alex",
                "Misconception": "Does not remember that an oblong has all right angles"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise a rectangle"
            }

```json

    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find 100 less than a given number",
            "Subject": "Place Value",
            "Question": "What number is \( 100 \) less than \( 214,852 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 214,752 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2148.52 \)",
                "Misconception": "Divides rather than subtracts when given the command 'less than'"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 214,952 \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 214,752 \) is incorrect in this option. Answer_D should be \( 213,852 \)",
                "Misconception": "When subtracting a power of 10, subtracts from the wrong column"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

Misconception 969/1869:
Here are the additional examples:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Perform calculations with temperature when given in the same units",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers",
            "Question": "Which statement about the temperatures \( -3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and \( 4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is true?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 1^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) 
                colder than 
                \( -3^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know that 3 and -3 are different"
            },
            "Answer_B": {

            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 82 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 98 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 66 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 998/1869:
Here's another example based on the same format and misconceptions:

```json
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables",
            "Subject": "Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms",
            "Question": "Simplify, if possible: 
\[
x+2y
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2xy \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses collecting like terms with multiplication"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( yx + 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x^{2y} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes addition of terms and powers of terms are equivalent e.g. x + 2y = x^2y"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not simplify",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Misconception 999/1869:
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret linear sections of real life graphs",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "The graph below represents the water level in a tank over time.

What might the horizontal section represent? ![A graph with time (minutes) on the horizontal axis and water level (cm) on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels in a straight line up and right, travels horizontally, then travels in a straight line down and right back to the x-axis, more steeply than the start. ]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "The heating system is turned off",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Water is being added to the tank",
                "Misconception": "Believes a horizontal line can show a constant rate of change"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Water is being drained from the tank",
                "Misconception": "Believes a horizontal line can show a constant rate of change"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "The tank is full",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 1004/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Shade percentages of a shape where the percent is an integer",
            "Subject": "Percentages of an Amount",
            "Question": "How many circles would you need to shade so that \( 35 \% \) of this shape is shaded? \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 35 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand a percentage is out of 100"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 70 \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies rather than divides"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Not possible",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand a percentage can be applied to something not out of 100"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

                "Answer_text": "\( 0.7 \)",

            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.27 \)",
                "Misconception": "Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing all values of the fraction after the decimal point"
            },

                "Answer_text": "None of these.",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }

Misconception 1008/1869:
Here are four new examples, each with the same misconception as the original:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{20}{x}=4
\)

Alex says a correct next line of working could be: \( 20=4 x \) 

Ben says a correct next line of working could be: \( 20=\frac{x}{4} \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    },
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Charlie and David are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{36}{x}=6
\)

Charlie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 36=6 x \) 

David says a correct next line of working could be: \( 36=\frac{x}{6} \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Charlie",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only David",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Charlie and David",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    },
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Emily and Frank are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{48}{x}=8
\)

Emily says a correct next line of working could be: \( 48=8 x \) 

Frank says a correct next line of working could be: \( 48=\frac{x}{8} \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Emily",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Frank",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Emily and Frank",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    },
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Gabriel and Hannah are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{30}{x}=5
\)

Gabriel says a correct next line of working could be: \( 30=5 x \) 

Hannah says a correct next line of working could be: \( 30=\frac{x}{5} \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Gabriel",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Hannah",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Gabriel and Hannah",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise perpendicular lines",
            "Subject": "Geometry",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing this pair of lines
Alex says they are parallel
Ben says they are perpendicular

        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the meaning of perpendicular"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not know what dashes on the sides of shapes mean"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Note that the correct answer is B, as the two lines intersect in the middle, making them perpendicular.

Misconception 1025/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Read the graphical solution to a pair of linear simultaneous equations from a diagram",
            "Subject": "Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations",
            "Question": "According to the graph, what are the solutions to the simultaneous equations? ![The image is of a set of axes with two straight lines drawn on.         },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=4, \quad y=0 \)",

            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=0, \quad y=2 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving simultaneous equations graphically, they think the solutions are the x-intercepts"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=1, \quad y=1 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=2, \quad y=2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },

    }

This example maintains the same format and misconceptions as the original question. The sequence is 35-7n, and the correct answer is the number of terms greater than zero in this sequence, which is 5.

Misconception 1030/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 2 decimal places",
            "Subject": "Converting between Fractions and Decimals",
            "Question": "Sam and Alex are discussing fractions, decimals and percentages. Sam says \( \frac{17}{25}=7. \) Alex says \( \frac{17}{25}=68 \% \) Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Sam",
                "Misconception": "Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Sam and Alex",
                "Misconception": "Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand equivalent fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Let me know if you need anything else!

Misconception 1031/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Divide integers of 3 or more digits using long division",
            "Subject": "Written Division",
            "Question": "When using long-division to solve this problem, what digit should replace the rectangle to give the correct answer (quotient)? ![Division sum written out in Bus Stop format with dividend = 945, divisor = 5, the digits of the quotient are represented by a green heart, an orange circle and a blue rectangle.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Starts at the wrong end of the dividend when dividing"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Subtracts instead of divides"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9 \)",
                "Misconception": "Starts at the wrong end of the dividend when dividing"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Misconception 1032/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "\( 3 \times 2 + 11= \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 22 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 17 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 36 \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies rather than adds "
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 14 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Note: The correct answer is indeed 17, since the correct order of operations is to multiply 3 and 2 first (getting 6), then add 11 (getting 17).

Misconception 1033/1869:
Here is another example of a question with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve basic introduction simultaneous equation problems, often involving shapes and symbols",
            "Subject": "Simultaneous Equations",
            "Question": "Tom buys \( 2 \) burgers and a drink, and his bill comes to £4.20

Lily buys \( 4 \) burgers and a drink, and her bill comes to £7.40.
How much does one burger cost?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 90 p \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 120 p \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving simultaneous equations, thinks they can ignore one of the variables"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "E2",
                "Misconception": "When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( £ 1.60 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Let me know if you'd like me to generate more examples!

            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing how to solve this quadratic equation:
\(
(3 x+4)(x-2)=0
\)

Alex says one solution is: \( x=\frac{4}{3} \)

Ben says one solution is: \( x=-\frac{2}{3} \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the sign of solutions in a quadratic equation is always the same as the constant term"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "Believes that the solution to ax + b = 0 is x = -a/b"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

        "question": {

            "Question": "Which ratio would you use to find the length of the adjacent side in a right-angled triangle where the hypotenuse is 8cm and the angle is 60°? ![A right angled triangle with the longest side labelled 8cm. The angle is 60°.]()"

                "Misconception": "nan"

                "Answer_text": "Tan",
                "Misconception": "Uses tan when cos is required"
            },

                "Answer_text": "None of these",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand how to apply sohcahtoa"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

            },

                "Misconception": "Believes the difference between triangle numbers remains the same"

        },

    }
]

Misconception 1053/1869:

[

\(

\)"

                "Answer_text": "\( (x-3)(x-4) \)",

                "Misconception": "Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer"
            },

                "Answer_text": "\( (x+3)(x-4) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+3)(x-6) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 1055/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconception for each answer:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Add proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Fractions",
            "Question": "The fractions in the two circles below add to give the fraction in the circle above.

What should replace the question mark? ![Fractions 2/3 and 2/5 in two separate circles, both linked to a third circle above.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{4}{8} \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{2}{15} \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding fractions, changes to common denominator but leaves numerators the same"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{8}{15} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{16}{15} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Misconception 1056/1869:
Here is another example with the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a term in an ascending integer linear sequence, use the nth term rule to find its position in that sequence",
            "Subject": "Linear Sequences (nth term)",
            "Question": "Here are the first \( 4 \) terms of a sequence \( \begin{array}{lllll}7 & 13 & 19 & 25 & \ldots\end{array} \) What position in the sequence is the number \( 103 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 19.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes you multiply the constant difference by the term number to get the term value"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 400 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 n-5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 21 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Note that I've generated a new sequence with a different starting point and common difference, and a new target value of 103. The misconceptions and answer formats remain the same.

Misconception 1057/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)",
            "Subject": "Factorising into a Single Bracket",
            "Question": "Factorise this expression, if possible:
](
x^{2}+36 x
)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x(x+36) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x-6)(x+6) \)",
                "Misconception": "When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+6)(x+6) \)",
                "Misconception": "When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not factorise",
                "Misconception": "Thinks a quadratic without a non variable term, can not be factorised"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 1058/1869:
Here is another example with the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object",
            "Subject": "Reflection",
            "Question": "A point, \( P \), has coordinates \( (2,-4) \)
The point is reflected in the line \( y=x \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (-2,-4) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes reflection in y = x changes sign of x coordinate only"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (2,4) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes reflection in y = x changes sign of y coordinate only"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (2,-4) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (-4,2) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes reflection in y = x switches x and y coordinates"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

In this example, the point P has coordinates (2,-4) and is reflected in the line y=x. The correct answer is ( Answer_D ) which is (-4,2).

Misconception 1060/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons",
            "Subject": "Properties of Polygons",
            "Question": "This polygon has all sides of equal length, what type of polygon is it? ![A shape with six equal sides.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Obtuse",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the meaning of the word equilateral"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Hexagon",
                "Misconception": "Does not know what equal sides in a polygon mean"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Irregular",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the meaning of the word equilateral"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Equilateral",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

In this example, the correct answer is "Equilateral" because the polygon has all sides of equal length. The misconceptions for the incorrect answers are:

* Answer A: Does not know the meaning of the word equilateral
* Answer B: Does not know what equal sides in a polygon mean
* Answer C: Does not know the meaning of the word equilateral

Misconception 1063/1869:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given an x value, find the corresponding y value from a non-linear graph",
            "Subject": "Cubics and Reciprocals",
            "Question": "Here is the graph of
\(
y=\frac{2}{x}
\)

What is the value of \( y \) when \( x=-2 \) ? ![A graph with two curves. Y axis from -5 to 5 and x axis from -5 to 5 marked in increments of 1.  One curve is in the positive x, positive y quadrant. It starts at the top close to the line x = 1, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the x axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the line y =1. It goes through (1, 2) (2,1) and (4,0.5).  One curve is in the negative x negative y quadrant. It starts at the top left of the quadrant almost parallel to y = -1, then we move right and it curves downwards towards the y axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the x = -1 line. It goes through (-4, -0.5) (-2, -1) and (-1,-2)]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes dividing a positive by a negative gives a positive answer"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -1 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {

                "Misconception": "Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines"
            },

                "Misconception": "Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x y=3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the equation for a horizontal line is in the form xy = a, where a is the y intercept"

            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },

[

The first function is 3x and the second function says 'added to 2'. The output is blank.]() Alex says the output is \( \mathbf{3} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{2} \)

Ben says the output is \( \mathbf{2}+\mathbf{3} \boldsymbol{x} \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Has not noticed the difference between 'add' and 'add to'"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",

            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }

]

Misconception 1075/1869:
Here is another example in the same format and with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify the region that satisfies a system of linear inequalities",
            "Subject": "Graphing Linear Inequalities (Shading Regions)",
            "Question": "Which region describes where \\(\\boldsymbol{x}<\\mathbf{0}\\) and \\(\\boldsymbol{y}>\\mathbf{0}\\) ? ![A set of axis showing all four quadrants. y axis from -3 to 3 and x axis from -3 to 3]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "A",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "B",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "C",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "D",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up greater than and less than symbols"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Note that the question and correct answer have changed, but the misconceptions for each answer remain the same.

Misconception 1076/1869:
Here is another example of the same question while maintaining the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify and represent sets using set notation",
            "Subject": "Probability of Single Events",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing the probability spinner

Alex says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{2,4,6\} \)

Ben says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{2,2,4,4,6,6,6\} \)
Who do you agree with? ![A circle divided into 7 equal sections. 3 of the sections are labelled with a green number 2. 3 of the sections are labelled with a yellow number 4. 1 of the sections are labelled with a red number 6.>()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Believes a sample space should show repeated outcomes, not just unique possible outcomes."
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

Please let me know if you need anything else!

A is in the x-2.1 is greater than or equal to 0 circle only.
B is in the overlap of the two circles.

D is outside both circles.]()"

Misconception 1081/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "A bakery sells a certain type of bread for \( £ 0.80 \) per loaf, with a fixed delivery charge of \( £ 2.00 \). Emily correctly sketches a graph to show the cost of buying different numbers of loaves. Which of the following graphs would best match Emily's sketch?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with number of loaves on the horizontal axis and cost on the vertical axis. The graph starts at a point on the positive horizontal axis and travels downwards and right in a straight line.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with number of loaves on the horizontal axis and cost on the vertical axis. The graph starts at a point on the positive vertical axis and travels horizontally right.]()",
                "Misconception": "Believes a horizontal line can show a constant rate of change"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with number of loaves on the horizontal axis and cost on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin and travels in a straight line right and upwards.]()",
                "Misconception": "Assumes that a graph always starts at the origin"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with number of loaves on the horizontal axis and cost on the vertical axis. The graph starts at a point on the positive vertical axis and travels upwards and right in a straight line.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 1097/1869:

            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the first term in a sequence is the term before the sequence begins (0th term)"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 25 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

In this example, the nth term rule is 3n + 2, and the correct first term is 5. The misconceptions are the same as before.

Misconception 1098/1869:
Here is another example with the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions",
            "Subject": "Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions",
            "Question": "STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{2 x-3}{4} \div \frac{4 x^{2}-9}{8} \\
= & \frac{2 x-3}{4} \times \frac{8}{4 x^{2}-9} \\
= & \frac{2 x-3}{4} \times \frac{8}{(2 x-3)(2 x+3)}
\end{aligned}
\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{8}{2 x+3} \)",
                "Misconception": "Only applies a division to one of multiple terms in a numerator when simplifying an algebraic fraction"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{2(2 x-3)}{(2 x-3)(2 x+3)} \)",
                "Misconception": "When simplifying an algebraic fraction, only looks for number factors"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3}{2 x} \)",
                "Misconception": "Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator and denominator"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{2}{2 x+3} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

\[

            },

            }

Misconception 1100/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c",
            "Subject": "Factorising into a Double Bracket",
            "Question": "Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(x^{2}+8 x+12\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+2)(x+6) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+12)(x+1) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+8)(x-1) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not factorise",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

This example illustrates the same misconceptions as the original question:

* Answer B thinks they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant (12), so they choose 12 and 1.
* Answer C thinks they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x (8), so they choose 8 and -1.
* Answer D doesn't factorise the expression at all.
* Answer A is the correct factorization, but has no misconception listed.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given information about one part, work out other parts",
            "Subject": "Sharing in a Ratio",
            "Question": "Tom and Alex share some sweets in the ratio \( 2: 5 \)

Tom receives 30 sweets.

How many sweets does Alex receive?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 75 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 25 \)",
                "Misconception": "In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, treats that as the total"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 15 \)",
                "Misconception": "Finds one part of a ratio but doesn't multiply that by the number of parts needed"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 60 \)",
                "Misconception": "Gets order of ratio wrong"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }

Misconception 1102/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Order negative decimals with the same number of digits",
            "Subject": "Ordering Negative Numbers",
            "Question": "Here are the temperatures in \( 3 \) cities:
City A: \( -3.8^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
City B: \( -5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
City C: \( -2.1^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)
Arrange their temperatures in ascending order, starting with the coldest"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1^{\text {st }} \) City A
\( 2^{\text {nd }} \) City C
\( 3^{\text {rd }} \) City B",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the more digits a number has the greater it is, regardless of place value"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1^{\text {st }} \) City C
\( 2^{\text {nd }} \) City B
\( 3^{\text {rd }} \) City A",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}1^{\text {st }} \text { City C } \\ 2^{\text {nd }} \text { City A } \\ 3^{\text {rd }} \text { City B }\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1^{\text {st }} \) City B \( 2^{\text {nd }} \) City A \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) City C",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Misconception 1103/1869:
Here is another example of the same question with the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative",
            "Subject": "Distance Between Two Co-ordinates",
            "Question": "Tom is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (-3,4) \) and \( (5,-2) \) He labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (-3, & 4) & (5, & -2)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the first bracket equal?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (8)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (3)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "When subtracting a negative number from a positive number, uses a method which assumes one of the negative signs can be ignored "
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (-8)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes subtraction is commutative "
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (2)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

```
[

        "question": {

                "Answer_text": "\(x \Rightarrow +3  \Rightarrow \times4\Rightarrow 4x+3\)

                "Misconception": "Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\(x \Rightarrow \times4  \Rightarrow +3\Rightarrow 4x+3\) 

\(x \Rightarrow \times4  \Rightarrow +3\Rightarrow 4(x+3)\) ",
                "Misconception": "Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked."

                "Answer_text": "\(x \Rightarrow \times4  \Rightarrow +3\Rightarrow 4x+3\) 

\(x \Rightarrow +3  \Rightarrow \times4\Rightarrow 4(x+3)\) ",
                "Misconception": "Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked."

                "Misconception": "Correct answer, but not chosen"

Misconception 1107/1869:
Here is another example of the same question, maintaining the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable",
            "Subject": "Simultaneous Equations",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}2 x+3 y=10 \\ x-3 y=-8\end{array} \) Alex says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Ben says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Ben",
                "Misconception": "Subtracts simultaneous equations when addition is required"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "When solving simultaneous equations thinks that identical terms in given equations can be eliminated by either adding or subtracting."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Let me know if you need anything else!

            }
        },

    }

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {

                "Misconception": "Assumes a fact without considering enough examples"

    }
]

            },

                "Misconception": "Believes the discriminant must be a perfect square for an equation to have real solutions"
            },

                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{-2 \pm \sqrt{0}}{1} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that a discriminant of 0 means there are no real solutions"

                "Answer_text": "![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right.                 "Misconception": "Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "+2" written inside the next rectangle, "✕ 3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3q + 2" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "q" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "+2" written inside the next rectangle, "✕ 3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3(q + 2)" written inside it.]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked."
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1118/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify whether two shapes are similar or not",
            "Subject": "Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes",
            "Question": "Samantha and Alex are discussing similarity. Who is correct? Samantha says these two triangles are similar ![Two triangles of different sizes. One triangle has base 3cm and height 4cm. The other triangle has base 6cm and height 11cm. ]() Alex says these two triangles are similar ![Two triangles of different sizes. One triangle has base 5cm and height 7cm. The other triangle has base 10cm and height 12cm. ]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Samantha",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that similar shapes sides must all have the same scale factor"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Thinks adding the same value to each side makes shapes similar"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Samantha and Alex",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that similar shapes sides must all have the same scale factor"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

\hline English & \( 50 \) \\
\hline History & \(  \) \\
\hline Geography & \( 20 \) \\

                "Misconception": "nan"

            "Question": "Here is a number line: ![A horizontal number-line with 13 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. The 1st dash is labelled with "-8", the 3rd dash is labelled "-6", the 5th dash is labelled "-4", the 7th dash is labelled "-2", the 9th dash is labelled "0", the 11th dash is labelled "2" and the 13th dash is labelled "4"    A red arrow, labelled with a question mark is pointing one-third from the 8th dash towards the 9th dash. ]() Which of the following numbers could be indicated by the arrow?"
        },
        "answers": {

                "Answer_text": "\( -2.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Counts on in the wrong direction on a number line"

Misconception 1129/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers",
            "Question": "![Diagram of a number line showing -5, -2, and 3, with an arrow labelled +3 going from -5 up to -2]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the number line?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -5+3=-2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5-3=2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a negative number can be replaced with its positive equivalent when answering an addition problem from a numberline"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -2+3=5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes we move down a number line when we add"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -5+(-2)=3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the number of jumps between two numbers on a numberline represents the sum of those 2 numbers "
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note: The diagram is a number line showing -5, -2, and 3, with an arrow labelled +3 going from -5 up to -2.

Misconception 1131/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconception for each answer:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Understand the non-commutativity of division",
            "Subject": "Mental Multiplication and Division",
            "Question": "Sai says the following:

"It doesn't matter if you do \( \mathbf{9} \div \mathbf{3 6} \) or \( \mathbf{3 6} \div \mathbf{9} \), you get the same answer"

What do you think?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Sai is correct because division is commutative",
                "Misconception": "Believes division is commutative "
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Sai is incorrect because division is commutative",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative "
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Sai is correct because division is not commutative",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative "
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Sai is incorrect because division is not commutative",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 1138/1869:
Here is another example of a question that maintains the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the denominator",
            "Subject": "Simplifying Algebraic Fractions",
            "Question": "Simplify the following: \( \frac{12 x^{4}}{8 x^{3}+4 x^{2}} \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{12 x^{3}}{8 x^{2}+4 x} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not fully simplify fraction"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3 x^{2}}{2 x+1} \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3 x^{3}}{2 x^{2}+x} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3 x^{4}}{2 x^{3}+x^{2}} \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Note that the correct answer is indeed C, which is `\( \frac{3 x^{3}}{2 x^{2}+x} \)`. The other answers exhibit the same misconceptions as before.

Misconception 1139/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find the area of rectilinear shapes by counting squares",
            "Subject": "Area of Simple Shapes",
            "Question": "What can you say about the areas of the two rectangles? ![A blue rectangle drawn on a grid, 4 grid squares wide, and 2 grid squares long. A red rectangle drawn on a grid, diagonally, with one corner on a grid intersection and the opposite corner 3 grid squares away.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "The blue rectangle has a larger area",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "The red rectangle has a larger area",
                "Misconception": "Counts half-squares as full squares when calculating area on a square grid"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "The areas are the same",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the diagonal of a rectangle is the same length as the side of the rectangle"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "It is impossible to say without measuring",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to find area by counting squares on a grid"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note: The diagram shows a blue rectangle with a width of 4 grid squares and a length of 2 grid squares, and a red rectangle with a diagonal that passes through 3 grid squares.

(just \( x \) inside brackets)",
                "Misconception": "nan"

Misconception 1143/1869:
Here's another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given the number of sides of a polygon identify the name",
            "Subject": "Properties of Polygons",
            "Question": "If you continue to join up the intersections of the curves with straight lines, which of the following regular polygons could you have constructed? ![A circle has been intersected by curves at 7 equally spaced intervals about its circumference]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "A hexagon",
                "Misconception": "Confuses hexagon and heptagon"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "An octagon",
                "Misconception": "Confuses heptagon and octagon"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "A heptagon",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "A triangle",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the meaning of the word regular "
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```
This example has a circle intersected by curves at 7 equally spaced intervals, and the correct answer is a heptagon. The misconceptions are similar to the previous example, with students confusing heptagon with hexagon or octagon, or not understanding the meaning of "regular".

                "Misconception": "Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket"

            "Question": "Tom is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (-3,4) \) and \( (6,-2) \) He labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (-3, & 4) & (6, & -2)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) \( \sqrt{(9)^{2}+(-6)^{2}} \) What is the distance between the points?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \sqrt{3} \)",

                "Answer_text": "\( \sqrt{117} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }

                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
