Misconception 1374/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b",
            "Subject": "Completing the Square",
            "Question": "\[
x^{2}+3 x+2 \equiv(x-a)^{2}+0.5
\]
What is the value of \( a \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b is the difference between a and the constant of the original quadratic"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3}{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Let me know if you need anything else!

Misconception 1375/1869:
Here is another example of the same question type, with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Round decimals to the nearest whole number",
            "Subject": "Estimation",
            "Question": "A bookshelf has 5 shelves, and each shelf can hold 4.3 boxes of books. Which calculation will give the best estimate of the total number of boxes the bookshelf can hold?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \times 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds every number up when estimating"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \times 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds down instead of up"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \times 4.3 \)",  // <--- correct calculation, but not a good estimate
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \times 4.5 \)",  // <--- not rounding to the nearest whole number
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1379/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {

            "Subject": "Substitution into Formula",
            "Question": "Calculate the surface area \( (A) \) of a sphere with radius \( (r)=3.5 \mathrm{~cm} \) \( A=4 \pi r^2 \)"

            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}A=4 \times \pi \times 3.5 \\ A=175.84\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "When multiplying fractions, multiplies the denominator"
            },
            "Answer_C": {

                "Misconception": "nan"

Misconception 1380/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise perpendicular lines",
            "Subject": "Parallel Lines",
            "Question": "![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. PQ is a horizontal line measuring 5 units. RS is a diagonal line, with a positive gradient of 2. TU is a horizontal line measuring 2 units. VW is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -2/3. XY is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 3. ZA is a horizontal line measuring 4 units. BC is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 3/4. DE is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -1/2.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to BC?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \mathrm{DE} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "TU",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and horizontal "
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \mathrm{ZA} \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and horizontal "
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( VW \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 1381/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Substitute numbers into a SUVAT equation to work out distance",
            "Subject": "Substitution into Formula",
            "Question": "\( s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \) What is the value of \( S \) when
\[\begin{array}{l} a=2 \\ u=4 \\ t=3\end{array}\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 12 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 72 \)",
                "Misconception": "When a variable in an expression has a power, thinks the power applies to the whole expression"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 22 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Note that I've kept the same format and misconceptions as the original example, but changed the values and the equation to create a new question.

Misconception 1382/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Fractions",
            "Question": "Work out: \( \frac{3}{5}-\frac{2}{9} \) Give your answer in the simplest form."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{29}{45} \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of subtracts"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{1}{14} \)",
                "Misconception": "When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{11}{45} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{1}{5} \)",
                "Misconception": "Forgets to change the numerators when finding equivalent fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 1384/1869:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c",

            "Question": "Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( x^{2}-16 \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x-4)(x+4) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x(x-16) \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise difference of two squares"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x-4)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the factorised form of repeated roots and the difference of 2 squares"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Cannot be factorised",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise difference of two squares"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

            "Question": "\( \left(2 \times 10^{3}\right)-\left(5 \times 10^{2}\right)= \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \times 10^{-5} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a negative power results in a negative answer"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \times 10^{1} \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating with numbers in standard form, just applies the operation to the number and the power separately"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1.5 \times 10^{3} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {

            }

Misconception 1394/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify the net of a prism",
            "Subject": "Nets",
            "Question": "This is the net of a... ![An image of five connected triangles. There is a central triangle with two identical triangles attached to its top and bottom sides. It then has another identical triangle attached to its right side.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Triangle",
                "Misconception": "Names one of the faces of a 3D shape rather than the 3D shape name"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Triangular prism",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Triangular pyramid",
                "Misconception": "Confuses pyramid with prism"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Triangularbased cuboid",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up cuboids and prisms"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```

In this example, the correct answer is a triangular prism, but the student may confuse it with a triangular pyramid (Answer C) or think it's a type of cuboid (Answer D). Alternatively, they may just recognize the individual triangles and not see the whole 3D shape (Answer A).

Misconception 1395/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c",
            "Subject": "Parallel Lines",
            "Question": "Sarah and Alex are debating about parallel lines. 
Sarah says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{5} \) are parallel. 
Alex says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{3} \) are parallel. 
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Alex",
                "Misconception": "Believes lines are parallel if they have the same y intercept "
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Sarah",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Sarah and Alex",
                "Misconception": "Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1398/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise a reciprocal graph from its shape",
            "Subject": "Cubics and Reciprocals",
            "Question": "Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a reciprocal function?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A curved graph that starts just below the x-axis on the right and travels left and very gradually down. Just before it reaches the y-axis it travels more steeply down and left, going through a point on the y-axis below the origin and continually steeply falling down and left. ]()",
                "Misconception": "Confuses reciprocal and exponential graphs"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with two curves, in the top left and bottom right quadrants. The top left curve starts up and left of the origin and travels steeply down and left, it then levels off to travel alongside the x-axis without touching it. The bottom right curve starts down and right of the origin, travels steeply up and right, it then levels off just above the x-axis without touching it.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A curved graph that starts in the bottom right, travels steeply up and left, turns to travel steeply down and left, to the origin, where it turns around to travel up and left again.]()",
                "Misconception": "confuses cubic and reciprocal graphs"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A curved graph, a symmetrical U shape. It starts in the top right, travels steeply down and left, turns at a point on the y-axis below the origin and travels steeply left and up.]()",
                "Misconception": "Confuses reciprocal and quadratic graphs"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Note that I've generated new graph descriptions that maintain the same misconceptions as the original example.

Misconception 1402/1869:

                "Misconception": "Thinks two variables next to each other represent addition"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": ""Add two to c and then multiply by d."",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": ""Add two to \( \mathrm{d} \) and then multiply by c."",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 1403/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension",
            "Subject": "Area of Simple Shapes",
            "Question": "The area of this trapezium is \( 72 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). What would the length of the base, \( a \), of the trapezium be? ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled as h and 8cm and the perpendicular height labelled with 9cm]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( a=9 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Uses only the base and perpendicular height when calculating the area of a trapezium"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( a=12 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a trapezium"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( a=18 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Uses only the base and perpendicular height when calculating the area of a trapezium"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( a=16 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

This example follows the same format as the original question, with the same misconceptions for each answer. The values and labels in the trapezium diagram have been changed, but the underlying misconceptions remain the same.

Misconception 1405/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise the equations of vertical lines from a diagram",
            "Subject": "Horizontal and Vertical Lines",
            "Question": "What is the equation of this line? ![A graph showing a vertical line going through a number on the x axis. The number is two boxes to the left of 5, where there are 4 boxes between 0 and 5.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Assumes every dash on a scale represents an increase of 1"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

In this example, the vertical line goes through a number on the x-axis that is two boxes to the left of 5, where there are 4 boxes between 0 and 5.

Misconception 1413/1869:
Here is another example of the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units",
            "Subject": "Compound Area",
            "Question": "What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape made from two rectangles that form a "T" shape.  The vertical height of the shape is 10cm long. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 8cm. The vertical height of the top rectangle is 3cm. The middle rectangle is shaded blue.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 80 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating the area of a rectilinear compound shape, calculates the are of the surrounding rectangle"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 41 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 26 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Calculates perimeter when asked for area"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Note that I've created a new composite shape with different dimensions, but the misconceptions remain the same.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons",

            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing hexagons.
Alex says if all the angles are Ben says if all the sides are equal equal then the hexagon must be length then the hexagon must be regular regular
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {

                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",

Misconception 1417/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a situation sketch an appropriate speed-time graph",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "A car accelerates slowly, then travels at a constant speed, then rapidly comes to rest. Which of the following velocity \( (v) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate the car's journey?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with time on the horizontal axis and velocity on the vertical axis. The graph at a point below the origin, travels horizontally right, travels up and right in a straight line, then travels horizontally right again.]()",
                "Misconception": "Thinks a graph starting below the origin means the car is initially moving backwards"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with time on the horizontal axis and velocity on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels right and up in a gentle straight line, travels horizontally right, then travels right and down in a steeper straight line than the start, until it reaches the horizontal axis.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with time on the horizontal axis and velocity on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels right and down in a straight line, travels horizontally right, then travels right and up in a more gentle straight line than the start.]()",
                "Misconception": "Believes a negative velocity means the car is moving backwards, not that it's decelerating"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A graph with time on the horizontal axis and distance on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels right and up in a gentle straight line, travels horizontally right, then travels right and down in a steeper straight line than the start, until it reaches the horizontal axis.]()",
                "Misconception": "Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

        "answers": {

            }

Misconception 1422/1869:
Here is another example of the question while maintaining the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive non-integer",
            "Subject": "Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x",
            "Question": "This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{9}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{2}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{9}{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies by the index"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \sqrt[3]{9} \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up square rooting and cube rooting"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 27 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Divides by the index"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 1423/1869:

[

Misconception 1427/1869:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Maya is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Maya's book. Maya always records what operation she has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 3 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( +3 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \times 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the inverse of addition is multiplication"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \div 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the inverse of addition is division"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }

                "Answer_text": "\( y=(x+2)(x+4) \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket"

        "Correct_Answer": "B"

Misconception 1429/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use a bar model to express a ratio problem",
            "Subject": "Sharing in a Ratio",
            "Question": "A bookshelf has 48 books, and they are shared in the ratio 4:3 between fiction and non-fiction books. Which of the following diagrams best represents this situation?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A bar split into 4 pink blocks and 3 blue blocks. All the blocks are the same size and each block is labelled 48.]()",
                "Misconception": "In ratio where total is given, treats that as one part without dividing"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A pink bar split into 4 blocks, and below it a shorter blue bar split into 3 blocks. All the blocks are the same size. The difference in length between the pink bar and the blue bar is labelled 48.]()",
                "Misconception": "When drawing bar diagram for ratio, shows the total as the difference between parts"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A bar split into 4 pink blocks and 3 blue blocks. All the blocks are the same size and the length of the whole bar is labelled 48.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A pink bar split into 4 blocks, and below it a shorter blue bar split into 3 blocks. All the blocks are the same size. The length of the pink bar is labelled 48.]()",
                "Misconception": "When drawing bar diagram for ratio, shows the total amount as the total of one side"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

This example maintains the same format and misconceptions as the original question. The question is slightly modified to fit a different scenario, but the answers and misconceptions remain the same.

Misconception 1430/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Add proper fractions with the same denominator",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Fractions",
            "Question": "Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{8}+\frac{2}{8}
\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3}{8} \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies the numerators when adding fractions with a common denominator"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{6}{64} \)",
                "Misconception": "When asked to add fractions, multiplies instead"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{5}{8} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{5}{16} \)",
                "Misconception": "When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Note that I've maintained the same format and misconceptions as the original example, and only changed the fractions being added and the corresponding answers.

Misconception 1431/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconception for each answer:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the square root of a number",
            "Subject": "Squares, Cubes, etc",
            "Question": "What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 20^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \square^{2} \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the sum of 2 numbers, each squared first, is the same as adding the two numbers and then squaring the total"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 33.3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Halves when asked to find the square root"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }

Misconception 1443/1869:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram",
            "Subject": "Horizontal and Vertical Lines",
            "Question": "What is the equation of this line? ![A graph showing a horizontal line going through 2 on the y axis.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=2 y \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the equation of a horizontal line is in the form x = ay, where a is the y intercept"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y=2 x \)",
                "Misconception": "Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x=2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

This question is similar to the original, but with a horizontal line going through 2 on the y-axis instead of 4. The same misconceptions are maintained for each answer option.

Misconception 1444/1869:
Here is another example of the question, maintaining the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use a protractor to measure angles between 90° and 180°",
            "Subject": "Measuring Angles",
            "Question": "Which diagram shows an angle of \( 150^{\circ} \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise, to the red line that is half way between 150 and 160 (inner scale) and halfway between 30 and 20 (outer scale).]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise, to the red line that is half way between 140 and 150 (inner scale) and halfway between 40 and 30 (outer scale).]()",
                "Misconception": "Chooses the correct scale when measuring angles on a protractor but starts from the wrong number when the angle is in between two labelled dashes"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise , to the red line that is half way between 30 and 40 (inner scale) and halfway between 150 and 140 (outer scale).]()",
                "Misconception": "Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the protractor, to the red line that is half way between 30 and 40 (inner scale) and halfway between 150 and 140 (outer scale).]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note that I've kept the same misconceptions and answer formats, but changed the angle being measured to 150° and adjusted the protractor diagrams accordingly.

                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }

Misconception 1451/1869:
Here is another example of the question with the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise that a sequence is linear sequences when expressed as a pattern",
            "Subject": "Linear Sequences (nth term)",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing linear sequences Alex says this is a linear sequence: ![Three rectangles with increasing number of squares: 2, 4, 6]() Ben says this is a linear sequence: ![Three rectangles with increasing number of squares: 2, 5, 8]() Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Alex",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

In this example, Alex's sequence increases by 2 each time (2, 4, 6), and Ben's sequence increases by 3, then 3 again (2, 5, 8). Both sequences are linear, but the incorrect answers assume that only one of them is correct.

\hline

                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that a number divided by itself equals 0"

                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"

            "Answer_A": {

Misconception 1457/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication",
            "Subject": "Mental Multiplication and Division",
            "Question": "Ava and Ben are calculating \( 24 \times 18 \) mentally Ava does \( 24 \times 10 \) and then adds \( 24 \times 8 \) Ben does \( 24 \times 9 \) and then doubles his answer Who would get the correct answer?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ava",
                "Misconception": "Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Ava and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

In this example, Ava and Ben are calculating 24 × 18 mentally using different strategies. Ava uses the distributive property to break down the multiplication into 24 × 10 and 24 × 8, while Ben uses a similar strategy to break it down into 24 × 9 and doubling his answer. The correct answer is indeed both Ava and Ben, as both methods will yield the correct result. The misconceptions for each answer option remain the same, highlighting the common mistake of not correctly applying the distributive property of multiplication.

        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Only applies a division to one of multiple terms in a numerator when simplifying an algebraic fraction"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Sam",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Sam",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1464/1869:
Here is another example of the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "A tennis ball is thrown upwards.
The graph on the right shows the ball's height in metres \( (h) \) over time in seconds
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the negative sloping section of the graph is \( 2 \).

Which of the following does that \( 2 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with h on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin, reaches a maximum, then slopes downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "The ball is moving upwards at a speed of \( 2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a downward slope on a height-time graph means moving upwards"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "The ball is accelerating down at a rate of \( 2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the gradient of a height-time graph is the acceleration"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "The ball is slowing down at a rate of \( 2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "The ball is falling at a speed of \( 2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Let me know if you need anything else!

            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Performs addition ahead of subtraction"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -1 \)",
                "Misconception": "Subtracts instead of adds"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

Note that I've maintained the same format and misconceptions as the original example, but with a new question and answers.

Misconception 1470/1869:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify the mode from a frequency table",
            "Subject": "Averages and Range from Frequency Table",
            "Question": "The frequency table shows the number of goals scored by a football team in a season.
What was the modal number of goals scored? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Goals & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the mode is the most common frequency rather than the highest frequency"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the mode is the frequency rather than the value/group"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 1474/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconception:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "\[
10÷2+4-1
\]
Alex and Ben are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 7 \).
Alex says you can write it like this: \( (10÷2)+4-1 \)
Ben says you can leave it like this: \( 10÷2+4-1 \)
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Misconception 1476/1869:
Here is an additional example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise a Fibonacci sequence expressed as a pattern",
            "Subject": "Other Sequences",
            "Question": "Which of the following is the best way to describe this sequence: ![A pattern with 6 terms made of yellow and blue dots. The first term is one yellow dot, the second is one blue dot, the third is one yellow and one blue dot. The fourth term is made of one blue and two yellow dots. The fifth term is made from two blue dots and three yellow dots. The sixth term is made of five yellow dots and three blue dots. ]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Linear",
                "Misconception": "Thinks any sequence that increases is linear"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Quadratic",
                "Misconception": "Confuses quadratic with any sequence that has a pattern"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Geometric",
                "Misconception": "Believes that Fibonacci sequences are a type of geometric sequence"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Fibonacci",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Note that I've maintained the same format and structure as the original example, and created a new sequence with a similar pattern, but with yellow and blue dots instead of green and red dots. I've also kept the same misconceptions for each answer option, with the exception of Answer A, which now has a new misconception.

A is the region right of x=2 and above y=2.
B is the region left of x=2 or below y=2.
C is the region right of x=2 or below y=2.

Misconception 1481/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the square of a number",
            "Subject": "Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals",
            "Question": "\( 0.4^{2}= \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.16 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.8 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.08 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1.6 \)",
                "Misconception": "When multiplying decimals, divides by the wrong power of 10 when reinserting the decimal"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

This example maintains the same format and misconceptions as the original question. The correct answer is 0.4^2 = 0.16.

Misconception 1485/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots",
            "Subject": "Distance Between Two Co-ordinates",
            "Question": "Tom is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (-3,-2) \) and \( (4,-8) \) He labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{rrrr}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (-3, & -2) & (4, & -8)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the first bracket equal?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (-1)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes subtraction is commutative "
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (7)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "When subtracting a negative number from a positive number, uses a method which assumes one of the negative signs can be ignored "
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (7)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (-7)^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Note: The question and answers are adjusted to fit the new example, but the misconceptions and formats remain the same.

Misconception 1486/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Add decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting with Decimals",
            "Question": "How should you line up the digits to calculate \( 2.3+0.98 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A column addition of 2.3 + 0.98. The 2 of 2.3 is directly above the decimal point of 0.98, the decimal point of 2.3 is directly above the 9 of 0.98 and the 3 of 2.3 is directly above the 8 of 0.98.]()",
                "Misconception": "Thinks that when adding decimals with a different number of decimal places, you should line up the digits to the right "
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A column addition of 2.03 + 0.98 with the decimal points lined up.]()",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A column addition of 2.3 + 9.8 with the decimal points lined up.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A column addition of 2.30 + 0.98 with the decimal points lined up.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }

Misconception 1490/1869:
Here is another example in the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret continuous data using a line graph",
            "Subject": "Time Series and Line Graphs",
            "Question": "This graph shows the daily rainfall in a city over a 7-day period.

In which 2-day period did the rainfall decrease the most? ![A graph showing the daily rainfall in a city over a 7-day period. At Mon the rainfall is 10 mm, at Tue it is 12 mm, at Wed it is 9 mm, at Thu it is 4 mm, at Fri it is 6 mm, at Sat it is 3 mm and at Sun it is 2 mm.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}\text { Tue to } \\ \text { Wed }\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}\text { Fri to } \\ \text { Sat }\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up heavier and lighter when comparing rainfall"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}\text { Thu to } \\ \text { Fri }\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{aligned} \text { Sun to } & \\ \text { Mon } \end{aligned} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 1492/1869:

[

            "Subject": "Probability of Single Events",
            "Question": "A coin is flipped, and the probability of it landing on its edge is \( 0 \).

What is the likelihood of the coin landing on its edge?"

        "answers": {

                "Misconception": "Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible"

                "Misconception": "nan"

Misconception 1493/1869:
Here is another example of the same question with the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "\( 2 + 3 \times 2^{2}= \) Which calculation should you do first?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \times 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes multiplication is carried out before a power"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 + 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "It doesn't matter: you get the same answer",
                "Misconception": "Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

This example presents the same misconceptions but with a different calculation. The calculation is `2 + 3 × 2²`, and the student is asked which operation to perform first. The misconceptions are the same:

* Answer A: Believes that the power should be calculated first (correct)
* Answer B: Believes that the multiplication should be carried out before the power
* Answer C: Believes that the operations should be carried out from left to right, without following the order of operations
* Answer D: Believes that the order of operations does not affect the answer to the calculation

Misconception 1494/1869:
Here is another example with the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Form expressions from situations described in words",
            "Subject": "Writing Expressions",
            "Question": "Which expression correctly represents the following description?
Add three to x and then multiply by four."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4(x+3) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4(3-x) \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds from left to right, ignoring the word ‘to’"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (3+x) \times 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds from left to right, ignoring the word ‘to’"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (x+3) \times 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

Note that I've kept the same misconceptions for each answer, but changed the description and expression to a new example.

Misconception 1495/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconception for each answer provided:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables",
            "Subject": "Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are arguing about what term could replace the star in this addition pyramid.
Alex says it could be: \( 2x \)
Ben says it could be: \( x \)
Who is correct? ![A diagram showing 3 rows of boxes. the bottom row has 3 boxes, containing a star, 5y and 3y from left to right. The next row up contains two boxes, overlapping the joins of the boxes below. Both are empty. The top row is one box, centered over the join of the two below, containing 3x + 8y.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Assumes an addition pyramid works in a different way to how it actually does"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "Assumes an addition pyramid works in a different way to how it actually does"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```
Note that I've kept the same format and misconception for each answer, but changed the names, variables, and numbers in the question.

        "question": {

            "Subject": "Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values",
            "Question": "This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(
y=x^{2}
\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling"
            },

                "Answer_text": "\( 9 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"

            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -9 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1497/1869:
Here's another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic",
            "Subject": "Solving Quadratic Inequalities",
            "Question": "Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}+2 x-8
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
x^{2}+2 x-8 \leq 0 ?
\) ![A quadratic parabola which crosses the x axis at (-4,0) and (2,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -8)]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \{x \geq-4\} \cup\{x \leq 2\} \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up greater than and less than symbols"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \{-4 \leq x \leq 2\} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \{-4 \geq x \geq 2\} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand inequality notation"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \{x \leq-4\} \cup\{x \geq 2\} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes inequalities cannot be combined"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```

This example has the same misconceptions as the original, but with a different quadratic inequality and graph.

Misconception 1505/1869:
Here is another example of a question with the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Construct a triangle using Angle-Side-Angle",
            "Subject": "Construct Triangle",
            "Question": "Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 60^{\degree} \) and \( 30^{\degree} \) either side?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "- Draw a line \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 60^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw a line \( 60 \mathrm{~cm} \) long that starts at the same end of the line and goes through the dot.
- Join up the end of this line with the other end of the \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) line.",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "- Draw a line \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Set the compass width to \( 60 \mathrm{~cm} \) and draw an arc from one end of the line
- Set the compass width to \( 30 \mathrm{~cm} \) and draw an arc from the other end of the line
- Join up the ends of the line to the intersection of the arcs with straight lines",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "- Draw a line \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 60^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 30^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle",
                "Misconception": "Draws both angles at the same end of the line when constructing a triangle"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "- Draw a line \( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 60^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the other end of the line, measure \( 30^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 1506/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 ",
            "Subject": "Quadratic Equations",
            "Question": "Which option gives a correct substitution into the quadratic formula to solve the quadratic equation? \( 3 x^{2}+5 x-2=0 \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \pm \frac{\sqrt{(5)^{2}-4(3)(-2)}}{2(3)} \)",
                "Misconception": "Misremembers the quadratic formula"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -5 \pm \frac{\sqrt{(5)^{2}-4(3)(-2)}}{2(3)} \)",
                "Misconception": "Misremembers the quadratic formula"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{5 \pm \sqrt{(5)^{2}-4(3)(-2)}}{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Misremembers the quadratic formula"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{-5 \pm \sqrt{(5)^{2}-4(3)(-2)}}{2(3)} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }

Misconception 1511/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconception for each answer:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Read values from piecewise functions",
            "Subject": "Other Graphs-Others",
            "Question": "Sarah has correctly drawn the graph of the following function:
\(
y=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
R \text { for } 1 \leq x<S \\
3.2 \text { for } 3 \leq x<5 \\
2 \text { for } 5 \leq x \leq 7
\end{array}\right.
\)

What are the values of \( R \) and S? ![The graph is three separate horizontal lines. It goes from (1,4.8) to (3, 4.8), then (3, 3.2) to (5, 3.2) and the last section is from (5, 2) to (7, 2)]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}R=4.8 \\ S=3\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}R=3 \\ S=4.8\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes."
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}R=1 \\ S=3\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}R=1 \\ S=4.8\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note: I've kept the same format and misconception for each answer, and only changed the values and variables in the question.

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a situation sketch an appropriate displacement-time graph",

        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![The graph has three sections.

                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![The graph has three sections.

                "Misconception": "Believes a less steep gradient corresponds to a faster speed"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is another sloped line with an even steeper positive gradient.]()",
                "Misconception": "Believes displacement continues to increase even when slowing down"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with steep, positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with a gentle, negative gradient.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

The second term is Pattern 1 but with 1 more blue circle and 2 more black sticks so that the 2 circles are enclosed by triangles made from black sticks. The third term is Pattern 2 but with 1 more blue circle and 2 more black sticks so that the 3 circles are enclosed by triangles made from black sticks.]() Alex says the number of circles in the \( 8^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of circles in the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) term.

    }

Misconception 1523/1869:
Here is another example of the same question, maintaining the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise if two linear expressions are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted",
            "Subject": "Simultaneous Equations",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing whether simultaneous equations are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted, or whether they need transforming first. Alex says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
3 x+2 y=12 \\
2 x-2 y=8
\end{array}
\) Ben says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
3 x+2 y=12 \\
3 x+y=10
\end{array}
\) Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "When solving simultaneous equations, believes the terms must be of opposite signs in order to be eliminated."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "When solving simultaneous equations, believes the terms must have the same sign in order to be eliminated."
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Let me know if you need more examples!

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables",
            "Subject": "Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms",
            "Question": "Simplify the following by collecting like terms.
\[
8 x+3 y-12 x-3 y
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -4 x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0-4 x \)",
                "Misconception": "When simplifying, thinks they write 0 in front of a negative number in the final answer, instead of just writing the negative number"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0 y-4 x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( y-4 x \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not think that a variable with no coefficient has a coefficient of 1."
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

This example has the same misconceptions as the original, but with different variables and coefficients.

Misconception 1529/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "\( 2.5 + \frac{3}{4} \div 1.5 = \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3.5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes addition is commutative "
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4.25 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1.75 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2.25 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Note: The misconception for Answer A is that addition is commutative, which is similar to the original example where the misconception was that subtraction is commutative.

Misconception 1530/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Multiply algebraic terms, where both are linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a x 2b)",
            "Subject": "Expanding Single Brackets",
            "Question": "What is the answer to \( 3 x \times 2 y \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 x y \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 32 x y \)",
                "Misconception": "When multiplying just writes the numbers next to each other"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 x y^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks any 2 values multiplied together can be denoted with a squared symbol"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 x y \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of multiplies when multiplying algebraic terms"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]
```

Misconception 1531/1869:
Here is another example of a question that maintains the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the shorter one",
            "Subject": "Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes",
            "Question": "These two shapes are similar (not drawn to scale).
What should replace the star? ![Two scalene triangles. The bigger one has sides 12 cm and 8 cm. On the smaller triangle, the side corresponding to the 12 cm is 8 cm, and the side corresponding to the 8 cm is marked with a star.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Doubles side length for similar shape instead of using correct scale factor"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6.4 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5.6 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks adding the same value to each side makes shapes similar"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Not enough information",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand how to find a scale factor"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1532/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconception for each answer provided:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition",
            "Subject": "Mental Addition and Subtraction",
            "Question": "This is how Alex calculates the answer to \( 54+29 \) mentally ![Cartoon picture of a boy's head with 2 thought bubbles:
First thought bubble says: "54+20 is equal to 74"
Second thought bubble says: "Then I am going to add on the 9.  74+9=83"]() Alex uses the same method to calculate \( 49+36 \). 
Which of the following shows how he would do this?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}49+6=55 \\ 55+30=85\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not copy a given method accurately"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}40+30=70 \\ 9+6=15 \\ 70+15=85\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}49+30=79 \\ 79+6=85\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not copy a given method accurately"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}6+9=15 \\ 40+15=55 \\ 55+30=85\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not copy a given method accurately"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```
Let me know if you'd like me to generate another example!

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative",
            "Subject": "Distance Between Two Co-ordinates",
            "Question": "Samantha is working out the distance between these two points. She has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the distance? ![The image is of two points (-3, -2) and (5,-5) joined by a sloped straight line, and then a horizontal and vertical line to create a right-angled triangle. The horizontal line is marked 8 and the vertical line is marked 3.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \sqrt{73} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 24 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not link Pythagoras Theorem to finding distance between two points"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \sqrt{50} \)",

            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \sqrt{64} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not rearrange the Pythagoras' Theorem formula accurately"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 1536/1869:
Here is another example in the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data",
            "Subject": "Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data",
            "Question": "What is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
4,5,6,7,9
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 31 \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating the mean from a list of data, adds up the numbers but does not divide"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the median"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the mode"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```

In this example, the correct mean is indeed 6, which is Answer B. The misconceptions in the other answers remain the same:

* Answer A adds up the numbers but doesn't divide by the number of items in the list.
* Answer C gives the median instead of the mean.
* Answer D gives the mode instead of the mean.

Misconception 1537/1869:
Here is another example of the same question with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Order decimals with a different number of digits",
            "Subject": "Ordering Decimals",
            "Question": "Alex and Maya are discussing how to order decimals
Alex says \( 0.09 \) is greater than \( 0.009 \)
Maya says \( 0.3 \) is greater than \( 0.3058 \)
Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Maya",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the more digits a number has the greater it is, regardless of place value"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Maya",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 1538/1869:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units",
            "Subject": "Area of Simple Shapes",
            "Question": "What is the area of this shape? ![A parallelogram drawn on a square grid in purple with an area of 12 square units. The base is length 4 squares and the perpendicular height is also length 3 squares.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \)",
                "Misconception": "Counts half-squares as full squares when calculating area on a square grid"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "Underestimates the area of shapes when counting squares when some squares are neither wholes nor halves"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 12 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9 \)",
                "Misconception": "Only includes fully shaded squares when counting area"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 1539/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret a pie chart",
            "Subject": "Pie Chart",
            "Question": "A survey was conducted to find out how students travel to school. A pie chart was created where 120 degrees represents students who walk to school. What does this mean?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Students who walk to school are the least common",
                "Misconception": "Believes you can make assumptions about size of pie chart sectors without enough information"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 33.3 \% \) of students walk to school",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Most students travel by bus",
                "Misconception": "Believes you can make assumptions about size of pie chart sectors without enough information"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 120 \% \) of students travel by car",
                "Misconception": "Believes a pie chart makes 360% not 360 degrees"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
