                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{3}{4}+x=3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand equivalent fractions"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }

Misconception 1718/1869:

            },

                "Answer_text": "\( x^{2}+10 x+25 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 1723/1869:
Here is another example in the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Expand double brackets with an extra variable outside",
            "Subject": "Expanding Double Brackets",
            "Question": "When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
p(p+5)(p-3) \equiv p^{3} \bigstar \ p^{2} \triangle \ p
\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \triangle=+2 \)
(no \( p \) term)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \triangle=+15 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \triangle=+8 \)",
                "Misconception": "When multiplying out 2 or more brackets, does not multiply all the combinations of terms"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \triangle=-15 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Let me know if you need more examples!

[

        "question": {

            "Subject": "Place Value",
            "Question": "What is the value of the \( 3 \) in this number?
\( 93527 \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not equate the value of a number with the place value column it is in"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30 \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the tens and thousands place value columns"
            },

                "Answer_text": "\( 30000 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 300 \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the hundreds and thousands place value columns"

Misconception 1725/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of both expressions",
            "Subject": "Simultaneous Equations",
            "Question": "If three bags of apples and four bags of oranges cost \( £ 12.20 \), and two bags of apples and five bags of oranges cost \( £ 10.50 \), what is the cost of a bag of apples and a bag of oranges?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Apples }=2 \\ \text { oranges }=1.5\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not include units in answer."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Apples }=£ 2.20, \\ \text { oranges }=£ 1.80\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Apples }=80 p \\ \text { oranges }=70 p\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Apples \( =80 p \) oranges \( =90 p \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 1729/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify that a problem needs to be solved using addition",
            "Subject": "Mental Addition and Subtraction",
            "Question": "Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Tom has 18 pencils in his pencil case. His friend gives him 4 more pencils.
How many pencils does Tom have now?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 18 \div 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Divides rather than adds when answering worded problems"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 18-4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems "
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 18+4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 18 \times 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

This example has the same misconceptions for each answer choice, but with a different problem scenario.

Misconception 1730/1869:

```

    {

            "ConstructName": "Identify the net of a prism",

On the right hand side is another rectangle identical to the one on the left. On the bottom side is a square identical to the top.]()"

                "Misconception": "Confuses pyramid with prism"
            },

            },
            "Answer_C": {

            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "This net would not create a 3D shape",

            }

    }
]

Misconception 1731/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing how to solve:
\(
 2x - 3 = 7 
\)

Alex says a correct next line of working could be: \( 2x = 10 \)

Ben says a correct next line of working could be: \( 2x-3=11 \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that when adding or subtracting a value from both sides of an equation, the same value must be added or subtracted from every term"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that when adding or subtracting a value from both sides of an equation, the same value must be added or subtracted from every term"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note that the misconception for Answer B and Answer C is similar to the original question, but with a different operation (addition/subtraction instead of multiplication).

The number 9 is outside the circles.]() How many students were surveyed in total?"

Misconception 1734/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconception for each answer:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting with Decimals",
            "Question": "This is how Alex calculates the answer to \( 8.2+3.9 \) mentally Alex uses the same method to calculate \( 4.1+27.8 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this? ![A diagram showing 3 thought bubbles from Alex's head. The first bubble says "I added the whole part first 8 + 3 = 11". The second bubble says "I then added the decimal part 0.2 + 0.9 = 1.1". The third bubble says "I then added 11 and 1.1 to get 12.1. So 8.2 + 3.9 = 12.1".]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}4+27=31 \\ 0.1+0.8=0.9 \\ 31+0.9=31.9\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}4.1+27=31.1 \\ 31.1+0.8=31.9\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not interpret the correct order of operations from a worded problem"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}4+27=31 \\ 0.1+0.8=0.9 \\ 31+0.9=31.09\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Ignores place value when adding a whole number and a decimal"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}4+27=31 \\ 0.1+0.8=0.018 \\ 27+0.018=27.018\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Let me know if you need anything else!

Misconception 1735/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation ",
            "Subject": "Solving Linear Inequalities",
            "Question": "Solve
\[
24 < 4(x-2) + 8
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x < 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the sides of an inequality can be switched without changing the direction of the sign"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{41}{4} < x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \frac{33}{4} < x \)",
                "Misconception": "When expanding brackets, multiplies out the first term correctly but adds together the number outside the bracket with the second term inside the bracket."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 < x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Note: The correct solution involves subtracting 8 from both sides, then dividing both sides by 4, and finally adding 2 to both sides, resulting in x > 3.

Misconception 1744/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Generate an ascending quadratic sequence from the nth term rule in the form ax² + bx + c",
            "Subject": "Quadratic Sequences",
            "Question": "Find the first \( 2 \) numbers in the sequence using the \( n \)th term \( 2 n^{2}-3 n+1 \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -2,3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0,-2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8,26 \)",
                "Misconception": "When squaring a variable, believes they also need to square the coefficient"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -2,4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```
Note that I've maintained the same misconceptions for each answer, and only changed the values in the question and answer options.

    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph",
            "Subject": "Speed, Distance, Time",
            "Question": "Here is a speed-time graph for a bicycle.

Which of the following gives the best estimate for the distance travelled between \( 2 \) and \( 4 \) seconds? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and speed in metres per second on the y axis. The curve passes through the points (2,8) and (4,12)]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 m \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 m \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that when finding area under graph you can use the upper y value rather than average of upper and lower"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 48 m \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that area under a speed time graph gives distance because distance = speed x time"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 m \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"

        },

            "Answer_A": {

                "Misconception": "Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. \"𝑥\" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has \"✕ 3\" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has \"- 2\" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to \"y\".]()",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up cubing and multiplying by 3 or tripling"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. \"𝑥\" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has \"cube\" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has \"- 2\" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to \"y\".]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. \"y\" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has \"- 2\" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has \"cube\" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to \"𝑥\"]()",
                "Misconception": "When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output."

        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }

Misconception 1762/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors",
            "Subject": "Translation and Vectors",
            "Question": "How would you describe the movement to get from the circle to the square? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 6, y-axis from 0 to 6. A blue circle symbol is at point (4,3) and a red square symbol is at point (1,5).]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \) squares right, \( 2 \) squares down",
                "Misconception": "When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \) squares up, \( 3 \) squares left",
                "Misconception": "Confuses left and right"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \) squares left,\( 5 \) squares down",
                "Misconception": "When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \) squares left, \( 2 \) squares down",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

This example has the same misconceptions as the original, but with a different geometric shape and coordinate points.

The y-axis is titled \"Number of toys sold\" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 4000 in steps of 500. The following points are plotted and joined together: (Jan, 1500), (Feb, 1800 approx.), (Mar, 2000 approx.),(Apr, 2200), (May, 2400 approx.), (Jun, 2500 approx.), (Jul, 2800), (Aug, 3000), (Sep, 3200), (Oct, 3500).
]() What was the total number of toys sold in the quarter (Apr, May, Jun)?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7200 \)",
                "Misconception": "Has used the wrong data point on the graph"

                "Answer_text": "\( 7400 \)",

Misconception 1764/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Determine the function of a single function machine used to create an algebraic expression",
            "Subject": "Function Machines",
            "Question": "Maya and Alex are discussing this function machine ![A function machine with an input of 2x-3, the function is not labelled and then an output of 8x-12]() Maya says the function could be \( × 4 \)
Alex says the function could be \( +2 x \)
Who do you agree with?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Maya",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Maya and Alex",
                "Misconception": "Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note: The misconception for answer C remains the same, as it is a common misconception that students may have when working with function machines.

Misconception 1765/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Translate a shape given vector notation where all values are positive",
            "Subject": "Translation and Vectors",
            "Question": "Tom has translated the green triangle \( \left(\begin{array}{l}4 \\ 2\end{array}\right) \) ![Image showing two identical triangles on a coordinate grid. The green triangle has the point (3,2) and the corresponding point on the blue triangle is (7,4).]() What error has Tom made?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Tom has moved up when he should have moved down",
                "Misconception": "Thinks a positive y value in a column vector means to move down rather than up"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Tom has not moved right the correct number of places",
                "Misconception": "When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares."
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Tom has counted from the wrong starting point when moving right",
                "Misconception": "When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Tom has not moved right the correct number of places",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

```
[
    {
        "question": {

            "Question": "Solve
\[
24 > 3(2x + 4)
\]"
        },
        "answers": {

                "Answer_text": "\( 4 > x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -4 > x \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( x > 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the sides of an inequality can be switched without changing the direction of the sign"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -2 > x \)",
                "Misconception": "Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

    {
        "question": {

            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Maya is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Maya's book. Maya always records what operation she has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 3 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -3 \)",

            },

                "Misconception": "Thinks the inverse of addition is division"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \times 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the inverse of addition is multiplication"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( +3 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            }
        },

    }

                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise the height of a trapezium as the perpendicular length between the parallel sides"

Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many borrowed on Wednesday and the upper one showing Thursday's borrowings. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 20, 20 and 40 etc.
The Fiction bar's lower section is 3 ticks high, and the whole bar is 1 tick above 40 on the vertical scale.]()"

            }

Misconception 1787/1869:
Here is another example of the question:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "A tank is being filled with water at a constant rate until the pump suddenly breaks down and no more water is added.

Which of the following sketches best shows the amount of water in the tank?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![This graph shows the amount of water in the tank increasing gradually and then suddenly leveling off at a certain level.]()",
                "Misconception": "Believes infinite gradient is not possible in real life. "
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![This graph shows the amount of water in the tank increasing gradually and then suddenly stopping at a certain level, with no more additions.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![This graph shows the amount of water in the tank increasing gradually and then suddenly decreasing at a rapid rate.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![This graph shows the amount of water in the tank staying at 0 for some time before increasing gradually and then suddenly stopping at a certain level.]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

In this example, the misconception for Answer A is that the student believes an infinite gradient (a sudden and instantaneous change) is not possible in real life, which is why they wouldn't choose the correct answer (Answer B).

Misconception 1788/1869:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise the place value of each digit in integers",
            "Subject": "Place Value",
            "Question": "What is the value of the \( 4 \) in the number
\[
94,217,865 \text { ? }
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the meaning of \"value\""
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 40,000,000 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4,000,000 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the millions column is the ten millions column"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4,000 \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the thousands and ten thousands place value columns"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```
Let me know if you need more examples!

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object",
            "Subject": "Reflection",
            "Question": "The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{Q} \) ? ![A coordinate grid with a reflection line drawn and a triangle. The reflection line passes through the coordinates: (-2,-2) (-1,-1) (0,0) (1,1) (2,2) etc. The triangle has coordinates: (-3,-1) (-2,-2) and (-1,-1). Q is the coordinate (-1,-1).]()"
        },
        "answers": {

                "Misconception": "Fails to reflect across mirror line"

            }

        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }

```
[
    {
        "question": {

            "Subject": "Solving Linear Inequalities",
            "Question": "What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(

\)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -5<x<11 \)",
                "Misconception": "When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -1.5<x<3.25 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -0.5<x<1.75 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes subtracting a positive number from a negative number makes the answer less negative"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -0.75<x<1.75 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```
This example is based on the same misconceptions as the original question, but with a new inequality: `-3<4x-2<7`.

Misconception 1804/1869:
Here is another example of the same question with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c",
            "Subject": "Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values",
            "Question": "This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=3x^{2}\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "When substituting a value into a non-linear term with a coefficient, multiplies by the coefficient then calculates the power."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Note that the correct answer is 9, since y = 3x² and x = 1, so y = 3(1)² = 3(1) = 9.

Misconception 1805/1869:
Here is another example of a question in the same format and with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise cube numbers",
            "Subject": "Squares, Cubes, etc",
            "Question": "What is the cube of 4?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 12 \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks numbers are a multiple of their index"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \)",
                "Misconception": "Mixes up odd and even numbers"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 64 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Note: The correct answer is indeed 64, since 4^3 = 64.

Misconception 1810/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret a bar chart",
            "Subject": "Block Graphs and Bar Charts",
            "Question": "The bar chart shows the number of students in each year group who participate in Basketball, Football and Volleyball.

How many more Year 9s than Year 8s participate in Football? ![An image of a vertical bar chart with bars striped orange for Basketball, solid green for Football and solid yellow for Volleyball (a key shows this). The x-axis is titled 'year group' with labels for Years 7 to 11. The y-axis is titled 'number of children' and its scale is from 0 to 60 in steps of 10. The following data is shown on the bar chart.
Year 7: Basketball 20, Football 30, Volleyball 40; Year 8: Basketball 25, Football 20, Volleyball 35; Year 9: Basketball 30, Football 40, Volleyball 20; Year 10: Basketball 15, Football 25, Volleyball 30; Year 11: Basketball 10, Football 15, Volleyball 25.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 60 \)",
                "Misconception": "Finds total instead of difference when asked 'How many more'"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 40 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 1812/1869:
Here is another example of the same question, maintaining the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative",
            "Subject": "Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates",
            "Question": "Here are two points and their midpoint. What should replace the star? ![A set of axis showing all four quadrants. Three points are marked in a straight line with a positive gradient. One lilac circle marks a point in the 4th quadrant and is labelled (3, -3). One red circle marks a point in the 2nd quadrant and is labelled (-1,-5). Another lilac circle marks a point in the 1st quadrant and is labelled (gold star icon, green triangle icon) as the coordinates are unknown. ]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\(\color{gold}\bigstar\) = -3",
                "Misconception": "Given a line segment with a midpoint that is not the origin, assumes that the two end points will still have the same absolute value"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\(\color{gold}\bigstar\) = 2",
                "Misconception": "Believes adding coordinates of endpoint and midpoint of a line will give the other endpoint"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\(\color{gold}\bigstar\) = 4.5",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\(\color{gold}\bigstar\) = 7",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Note that I've maintained the same misconceptions for each answer, and only changed the values and coordinates in the question.

Misconception 1813/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Find the area of non-rectilinear shapes by counting squares, where all squares are either whole or exactly half-squares",
            "Subject": "Area of Simple Shapes",
            "Question": "Each square is \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \)

What is the area of this shape? ![A 9 by 6 centimetre squared grid. A purple right angled triangle is drawn on the grid with a base of 4cm and a perpendicular height of 5cm.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Underestimates the area of shapes when counting squares when some squares are neither wholes nor halves"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a triangle"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

Note: The correct answer is indeed D, which is 10 cm^2.

Misconception 1814/1869:
Here's another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication",
            "Subject": "Mental Multiplication and Division",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing ways to calculate \( 36 \times 8 \) mentally
Alex multiplies \( 36 \) by \( 10 \) and then subtracts \( 36 \) from the answer.
Ben does \( 40 \times 8 \) and then subtracts \( 8 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Believes that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers can only be used one way round."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Believes that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers can only be used one way round."
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not think that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers is valid."
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

This example maintains the same format and misconceptions as the original question, with a new calculation scenario (\( 36 \times 8 \)) and new characters (Alex and Ben).

Misconception 1820/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format with the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify corresponding angles",
            "Subject": "Angle Facts with Parallel Lines",
            "Question": "\( \mathrm{A} \) and \( \mathrm{B} \) are the intersections of the line \( W Z \) with the lines \( T U \) and \( V R \).
Which angle is corresponding to angle UAW? ![A pair of parallel lines pointing up to the right. TU and VR are the ends of the parallel lines. TU is on the left of the diagram with U being the top left.
A red straight line, WZ, crosses the parallel lines. W is on the left of the diagram.
Line WZ crosses line TU at a point marked A.
Line WZ crosses line VR at a point marked B.
The angle UAW is marked in red.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "WAB",
                "Misconception": "Confuses corresponding and vertically opposite angles"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "RBW",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "RBZ",
                "Misconception": "Confuses co-interior and corresponding angles"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "WBR",
                "Misconception": "Confuses corresponding and alternate angles"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```

Note that I've kept the same format and misconceptions as the original question, but with a new diagram and angle labels.

Misconception 1822/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative",
            "Subject": "Translation and Vectors",
            "Question": "Which vector correctly describes the translation that maps object \( R \) onto object \( S \)? ![The image shows a pair of axes and two congruent triangles labelled R and S. Triangle R has vertices at (-2, 3), (-1, 1), (0, 3). Triangle S has vertices at (1, -2), (2, 0), (3, -2).]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \left(\begin{array}{c}3 \\ -5\end{array}\right) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \left(\begin{array}{c}-5 \\ 3\end{array}\right) \)",
                "Misconception": "Thinks the movement of the top number in a column vector is vertical, and the bottom number is horizontal rather than the other way round"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \left(\begin{array}{c}5 \\ -3\end{array}\right) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \left(\begin{array}{c}-3 \\ 5\end{array}\right) \)",
                "Misconception": "When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note: The correct answer is indeed A, since the translation from object R to object S can be described by a vector with a horizontal component of 3 and a vertical component of -5.

        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Recognise perpendicular lines",

TU is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -3. VW is a horizontal line measuring 4 units. XY is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 2. ZA is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -2. BC is a horizontal line measuring 2 units. DE is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 3.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to \( \mathrm{BC} \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \mathrm{RS} \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the meaning of perpendicular"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \mathrm{PQ} \)",
                "Misconception": "Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and vertical "
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "DE",
                "Misconception": "Does not know the meaning of perpendicular"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \mathrm{ZA} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Misconception 1832/1869:
Here is another example of a question with the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Describe the properties of a rhombus",
            "Subject": "Properties of Quadrilaterals",
            "Question": "A rhombus must have ..."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "all internal angles being right angles.",
                "Misconception": "Confuses rhombus and rectangle"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "two pairs of opposite sides of equal length.",
                "Misconception": "Confuses rhombus and kite"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "all sides of equal length and all internal angles being equal.",
                "Misconception": "Confuses rhombus and square"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "all sides of equal length and opposite sides being parallel.",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

In this example, the question asks about the properties of a rhombus, and the answer choices reflect common misconceptions about rhombi, such as confusing them with rectangles, kites, or squares.

Misconception 1833/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Determine the function of a single function machine used to create an algebraic expression",
            "Subject": "Function Machines",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing this function machine ![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "x" written inside it. The middle rectangle is empty and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "2x" written inside it.]() Alex says the function could be \( +x \)

Ben says the function could be \( \times 2 \)

Who do you agree with?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand when like terms can be collected"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Note that the only changes are in the question text, where the input and output values have been changed, but the underlying misconception remains the same for each answer option.

Misconception 1834/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use inequality notation to order integers with the same number of digits",
            "Subject": "Place Value",
            "Question": "Which symbol makes the following statement correct?
\[
2,478,123 \quad
 \square \quad
2,472,819
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( < \)",
                "Misconception": "When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( = \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand inequality notation"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "None of these",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand inequality notation"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( > \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

This example still has the same format and misconceptions as the original, but with different numbers and the correct answer being the opposite inequality symbol.

Misconception 1835/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph",
            "Subject": "Distance and Speed",
            "Question": "A car travels at a constant speed of 60 km/h. 
Which of these graphs shows the distance travelled in the first 4 hours?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "![A curved line graph from the origin. Y axis labelled distance in km extending to 240, x axis labelled time in hours extending to 4]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "![A straight horizontal line graph from 240 on the y axis. Y axis labelled distance in km extending to 240, x axis labelled time in hours extending to 4]()",
                "Misconception": "Believes a constant speed graph is a horizontal line"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "![A straight line graph from the origin. Y axis labelled distance in km extending to 240, x axis labelled time in hours extending to 4]()",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "![A straight line graph from approx 30 on the y axis. Y axis labelled distance in km extending to 240, x axis labelled time in hours extending to 4>>()",
                "Misconception": "Believes a constant speed graph does not have to start at the origin"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

This example maintains the same format and misconceptions as the original question, but with a new scenario involving distance and speed.

Misconception 1843/1869:
Here is another example with the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "A car is traveling along a road.
The graph on the right shows the car's speed in kilometres per hour \( (v) \) over time in hours
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the positive sloping section of the graph is \( 2.5 \).

Which of the following does that \( 2.5 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with v on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 1/2 of the way up the graph, 1/4 across the graph.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "The car is traveling at a speed of \( 2.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the gradient of a speed-time graph is the speed"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "The car is accelerating at a rate of \( 2.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "The car has traveled a distance of \( 2.5 \) km",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "The car is decelerating at a rate of \( 2.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes a upward slope on a speed-time graph shows negative acceleration"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

[
    {
        "question": {

            "Question": "\( y=(x-4)(x-2) \) \( y=(x-4)(x-2) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis? Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (0,-6) \) \( (0,-6) \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}(0,4) \\ \text { and } \\ (0,2)\end{array} \) \( \begin{array}{c}(0,4) \\ \text { and } \\ (0,2)\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that the y intercept is where y = 0"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (0,8) \) \( (0,8) \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (0,-8) \) \( (0,-8) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

            },

                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that subtracting a larger number from a smaller number will give a negative answer"

```
[
    {
        "question": {

            "Question": "This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{x}^{\mathbf{3}} \) ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & W \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() What should replace the star?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds the index to the number"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 9 \)",
                "Misconception": "Multiplies by the index"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 27 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 333 \)",
                "Misconception": "Writes the index as a digit on the end of a number"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Misconception 1850/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate distance where speed and time are in the appropriate units",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "This displacement-time graph shows \( 8 \) seconds of Alex's jogging route.

During that time she travelled at a speed of \( 20 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

What distance should replace the star? ![The graph has its vertical axis labelled Distance (m) and it has no scale written except for a star two squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 in even steps.
The graph is a straight line sloping down from (0, star) to (8, 0).
]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 m \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes scales on graphs must match on both axes"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "Makes an assumption about the squares on a scale representing either 1 or 10"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2.5 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes distance = speed/time"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 160 \mathrm{~m} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Note: I've changed the values in the question, but kept the same misconceptions for each answer.

```

Let me know if you need anything else!

Misconception 1853/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed",
            "Subject": "Rearranging Formula and Equations",
            "Question": "The formula for the distance, \( d \), travelled by an object is ![_object moving at speed v for time t]() \( d=v \times t \) Rearrange this to make the speed, \( v \), the subject."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( v=\frac{1}{t}(d \times t) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes they can change the subject of a formula just by swapping two letters"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( v=\frac{t}{d} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes dividing by a unit fraction is equivalent to dividing by its reciprocal"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( v=\frac{d}{t} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "They are all incorrect",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Let me know if you need anything else!

            "Question": "![A speed-time graph. The vertical axis is labelled Speed (km/h), with no scale labelled but 3 squares up is marked v.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (hours) and the scale is 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in even steps.
The graph first has a horizontal line from (0,v) to (1,v) and then a sloped line from (1,v) to (3,0).]() Work out the speed \( v \) if the distance travelled is \( 72 \) km."
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 18 \mathrm{km/h} \)",

        "question": {

            "Question": "The formula for finding the force is

\(
\text { force }(F)=\frac{\text { mass }(m) \times \text { acceleration }(a)}{1}
\)

Which of the following are not correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( F=\frac{m a}{1} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"

                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( m a=F \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to simplify algebraic fractions"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "All are incorrect",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"

Misconception 1857/1869:
Here is another example of the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the median as an average from an odd numbered list of data",
            "Subject": "Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data",
            "Question": "What is the median of the following numbers?
\( 3,5,7,9,11 \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7.4 \)",
                "Misconception": "Finds the mean instead of the median"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Finds the mode instead of the median"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "When finding the median for an odd numbered data set, find the midpoint of two values rather than giving the middle value"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Note that I've generated a new question with a different set of numbers, but the misconceptions and answer formats remain the same.

Misconception 1858/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Identify when it is appropriate to use a line graph",
            "Subject": "Time Series and Line Graphs",
            "Question": "Which of the following situations would a line graph be the most appropriate to use?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Showing the colors of cars in a parking lot",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that a line graph shows a relationship between 2 variables"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Showing the types of flowers in a garden",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that a line graph shows a relationship between 2 variables"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Showing how the temperature has changed over the past week",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Showing the ages of students in a classroom",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand that a line graph shows a relationship between 2 variables"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

In this example, the correct answer is still the one that shows a relationship between two variables over time (Answer C: Showing how the temperature has changed over the past week). The other options do not meet this condition, and the corresponding misconceptions are the same as before.

Misconception 1859/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Read values off a velocity-time graph",
            "Subject": "Time Series and Line Graphs",
            "Question": "This graph shows the velocity of a car from a starting point at various times. 
What was the change in velocity between 3 and 4 seconds? ![A velocity versus time graph]() This graph velocity from a start"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1.5 \ \text{m/s} \)",
                "Misconception": "When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points. "
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4.5 \ \text{m/s} \)",
                "Misconception": "When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points. "
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \ \text{m/s} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 5 \ \text{m/s} \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of subtracts when asked to find the difference"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 1860/1869:
Here is another example:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving negative integers",
            "Subject": "Linear Equations",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(2x + 3 = 5x - 2\)

Alex says you can write: \(2x + 5 = 3x\)

Ben says you can write: \(3 = 3x - 2x - 2\)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise that to maintain balance in an equation they must add or subtract the same amount from both sides"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Misconception 1861/1869:
Here is another example of a question with the same format and misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Round integers to the nearest 10",
            "Subject": "Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)",
            "Question": "What is \( 427 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 400 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 420 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds down instead of up"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 430 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 440 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]
```

Misconception 1862/1869:
Here is another example of the question in the same format and with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units",
            "Subject": "Compound Area",
            "Question": "Maria, Jake and Emily want to find the area of the backyard. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape made up of two rectangles.  Dimensions are 8 metres by 10 metres and also 3 metres by 5 metres. Two sides do not have measurements so need to be deduced]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Maria: \( 10 \times 8+5 \times 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Jake: \( 11 \times 8+3 \times 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Emily: \( 10 \times 11-8 \times 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "They are all correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Misconception 1864/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the range from a list of data",
            "Subject": "Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data",
            "Question": "What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
3, 7, 2, 19, -4
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 7 \)",
                "Misconception": "Finds the mode rather than the range"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 15 \)",
                "Misconception": "To find the range adds the biggest and smallest number rather than subtract"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 23 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 17 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not include negative numbers when calculating a range"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Note that I've maintained the same misconceptions for each answer, and only changed the numbers in the question and the corresponding answer options.

Misconception 1865/1869:
Here is another example based on the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1",
            "Subject": "Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes",
            "Question": "Shape \( R \) is an enlargement of shape \( S \).
What calculation works out the constant of proportionality from shape \( S \) to shape \( R \) ? ![To similar triangle shapes labelled S and R. They have the same side labelled for S it is 2cm and for R it is 6cm]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \div 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating a scale factor, thinks the division is the other way around."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 \div 2 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 2 \times 6 \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating a scale factor, multiplies instead of dividing."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6-2 \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating a scale factor, thinks they need to subtract rather than divide."
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1866/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "What does the following equal?
\[
12 \div 4 - 5 + 2 \times 3
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 14 \)",
                "Misconception": "Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 11 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]

Note that I've kept the same misconceptions for each answer, but changed the question and the correct answer.

Misconception 1867/1869:
Here is another example of the question with the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Distinguish between congruency and similarity",
            "Subject": "Congruency in Other Shapes",
            "Question": "Alex and Emma are discussing congruence and similarity. Who is correct? Alex says these two circles are congruent ![An image of two circles. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]() Emma says these two circles are similar ![An image of two circles. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Emma",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Emma",
                "Misconception": "Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1868/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format with the same misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object ",
            "Subject": "Rotation",
            "Question": "Sarah and Alex are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( R \) to shape \( S \)

Sarah says: "a rotation of \( +90^{\degree} \) clockwise"

Alex says: "a rotation of \( 270^{\degree} \) about \( (3,-2)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two triangles drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, three spaces to the right and two spaces down from the origin. Triangle R has the coordinates: (2,3) (4,3) and (3,2). Triangle S has the coordinates: (5,-1) (7,-1) and (6,-2).]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Sarah",
                "Misconception": "Forgets to give the centre of rotation"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Sarah and Alex",
                "Misconception": "Forgets to give the centre of rotation"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not know about the + notation for directions in rotations"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Let me know if you need more examples!
